land rights are the cornerstone of world economies university of melbourne researchers are helping the indonesian government modernise their land information system the road map towards beter land administration is based on local neds as wel as international best practices university of melbourne researchers have prepared customised road map of projects to modernise every aspect of indonesia land information system for the indonesian ministry of land afairs and spatial planing kementerian agraria dan tata ruang badan pertanahan nasional modern land information systems give clarity around land rights and suport land administration sustainable development and urban planing the university of melbourne centre for spatial data infrastructures and land administration csdila has previously worked on similar projects with the victorian government the world bank and the united nations comite of experts for global geospatial information management un gim the centre for spatial data infrastructures and land administration team is helping the indonesian government to move from paper based land administration to digital based land administration says profesor abas rajabifard the lead of the land information modernisation project land administration conects physical information about the land features with legal information about the rights restrictions and responsibilities this is done through series of steps and protocols al of which the research team has considered for modernisation based on the indonesian government vision and international best practices profesor rajabifard and his team have developed customised road map of projects to modernise indonesia land information system the partnership has also included training and capacity building acros the range of people involved in indonesian land administration proceses from land surveyors to government executives we are grateful for the training organised by csdila in which provided us with the oportunity to gain knowledge from csdila experts in the field of land management and cadastre this knowledge has alowed us to solidify our practical knowledge and increase the capacity of our staf to asist in the organisation of various activities in the ministry says himawan arief sugoto senior advisor to the minister the university of melbourne team is now working on pilot for modernised land information system caled smartland indonesia land rights form the basis of world economies modernising land administration gives clarity around land rights in disasters like flods or landslides paper records can be lost or destroyed the government may not know who the land rights should be returned to digital records also alow more information to be stored and conected and having complete land information available acros jurisdictions is important for emergency management urban planing and land managem ent it could reveal comunity resilience to natural disasters for example comunity could be at risk of floding due to the land topography and have por aces to road networks to escape modern land information systems can also power sustainable development digital records alow governments to beter analyse how land is distributed the equal aces to services and facilities is one part of the sustainable development indicators says profesor rajabifard many of the united nations sustainable development goals are conected to land beter land information alows beter measurement of progres towards those goals the world bank recognises land rights as cornerstone of world economies in and it sent group of indonesian executives to melbourne for workshop on best practices in land administration and what modernisation of land administration loks like the indonesian ministry of agrarian afairs and spatial planing asked the university of melbourne team to suport their project management ofice on their land system modernisation journey we started exploring al the busines proceses on diferent levels like the federal government the regional and also the local governments in diferent jurisdictions acros the entire indonesia says dr soheil sabri the manager of the land information modernisation project many changes are neded for fuly modernised land information system even in law for example in the indonesian context the land title should be printed and stamped by the legal ofice dr sabri says to fuly digitise the indonesian land administration system that law would ned to change the road map built by the university of melbourne proposed suite of projects to adres similar chalenges and oportunities modernising al aspects of the land administration workflow beyond digitising paper based system smartland indonesia may eventualy integrate digital twin technology digital twin virtual representation of real world entities and proceses synchronised with its real world equivalent could help convert land information system into giving more holistic view of structures such as high rise buildings in areas like jakarta learn more about infrastructure research the centre for spatial data infrastructures and land administration csdila was established in csdila was funded by the victorian government land ofice to explore transitioning its paper based land administration to digital system the victoria eplan was pilot project launched in in partnership with land use victoria it focused on the automatic validation of data colected and submited to the land ofice that is one of the flagship projects that converted the research into practice over those five years the team has learned lot of new knowledge and generated that knowledge as repository for moving forward in diferent directions says profesor rajabifard develope countries like australia and developing countries like indonesia face diferent chalenges in land administration but work on the victoria eplan project helped csdila contribute to international land administration frameworks for the world bank and the united nations global geospatial information management un gim these frameworks are internationaly recognised references for developing renewing reforming strengthening modernising or monitoring land information systems they help countries achieve sustainable development goals work on these international land administration frameworks led to the csdila introduction to un and world bank member states including the indonesian government indonesian ministry of land afairs and spatial planing kementerian agraria dan tata ruang badan pertanahan nasional centre for spatial data infrastructures cities are major source of carbon emisions our expert panel discused how we reduce the climate impact of the built environment the legal profesion is finaly experiencing the digital disruption that has swept through so many industries over the last decade it transforming al aspects of lawyering creating new ways of working in new markets with new roles and opening up new oportunities while traditional conventions wane law graduates who understand the impact of digital inovations and are comfortable working with technology wil be at an advantage with employers so legal education neds to provide students with the technical skils to thrive in the digital world and also the ability to navigate the complex ethical legal and social implications of new technologies while our future lawyers ned to work in digital world it remains al the more important to recognise the value of some important elements of traditional legal education including research critical thinking and analytical skils this blend of old and new capabilities is the best chance we have to thrive in rapidly changing world there are areas where the digital transformation wil be significant we re already seing the impact in discovery where artificial inteligence is both replacing work product from lawyers and at the same time improving the experience of law practice other changes might create new types of legal work in new markets for example providing online high volume low cost advice to under served constituencies at melbourne law schol for example the students in our law aps clas work in teams with not for profit clients to develop on line legal information sources to provide asistance to those who might otherwise strugle to understand their legal rights and duties other aspects of the law however wil remain more complex and nuanced and require greater human input than predicted by those who forese the end of traditional law firms as legal educators we ned to draw on the best of the past while being inovative about responding to the future some of the traditional values of high quality legal education remain pertinent maybe even increasingly so in rapidly changing world these elements should not be sacrificed when loking at reforms although the precise way in which they are taught may ned some modification the nature of legal research for example might be changing but the ned for high quality research skils is not careles and il defined search can give rise to torent of barely relevant unimportant materials from around the world the porly trained law graduate haplesly reproduces as much of it as posible hoping that the right answer wil mysteriously arise from the sea of information students must understand the questions they are researching have dep familiarity with the best research tols for the particular task understand the hierarchies at play in terms of court structures and forms of law and have god judgment about which sources to use and when none of these skils is straightforward and al of them require seriou educational efort both in law schol and in profesional training creating oportunities for serious dep and structured interdisciplinary experiences is another important aspect of contemporary legal education it is likely interdisciplinary groups wil give rise to the most inovative workplaces and solve the most intractable problems of our time for profesion in which development has tended to be evolutionary and incremental for much of its history the legal profesion is now faced with pace of change that has put serious presure on many lawyers as law firms examine their practices and adjust to the new world other competitors and new ways of providing legal advice emerge the patern of change and chalenge to the existing ways of doing things is likely to continue indefinitely law schols likewise face chalenges in responding to this new environment with the number of graduate places for young lawyers diminishing they must focus on both readying their students for those places and also preparing them for other roles in which their knowledge and skils can be used in adapting to met these new chalenges it is important law schols recognise that some of the traditional skils they impart to students wil continue to be valuable for long time to come but neither can they close their eyes to the environment into which students are graduating and they ned to be inovative and responsive in creating oportunities for students to develop new skils sets that wil set them up to suced even as the expectations of lawyers continues to shift over time to mark law wek may pursuit is loking at some of the isues facing the profesion in the st century baner image lady justice by alex proimos from sydney australia wikimedia can knowing to much harm us when it comes to medicine in some cases yes absolutely finding and treating diseases early saves lives and reduces health costs it is why health systems have ben increasingly undertaking proactive screning administering clinical tests on individuals who don have any symptoms but may be at risk examples include screning for diseases like bowel cancer or breast cancer the ubiquity of digital technologies in our lives has the potential to take proactive screning to new level digital screning this involves using information colected by our smartphones smartwatches keyboards social networks and wearable technology and analysing it using artificial inteligence algorithms to identify at risk individuals for example the early onset of parkinson disease could be identified from the changing paterns of how someone types while the risk of heart problems can be identified from abnormal heart rhythms detected by smartwatch while al this may sound god the problem is that proactive screning can find things that might not be worth finding there is overwhelming evidence that some diagnostic tests used in screning can find abnormalities that while meting the curent definition of disease might have never made some people sick these diseases that would have never generated any problems are what we cal cases of overdiagnoses and can lead to unecesary and sometimes harmful treatments and the emergence of digital screning could make this problem worse overdiagnosis as phenomenon has ben sen in many wel known diseases from some comon cancers to atention deficit disorder the most comon scenario of overdiagnosis is when we actively sek diseases in asymptomatic patients especialy among healthier segments of the population for example in some countries screning for thyroid cancer has led to two fold increase in the incidence of thyroid cancer but no change in mortality in other words the screning hasn reduced deaths similarly studies have shown that screning for atention deficit hyperactivity disorder in children can lead to simply the youngest children in schol clas being diagnosed overdiagnosis has ben observed for many cancers including prostate cancer and breast cancer as wel as conditions like chronic kidney disease gestational diabetes high blod presure and autism spectrum disorder the extent of overdiagnosis is dificult to quantify but one report has sugested that an estimated per cent of al cancers in australia may be cases of overdiagnosis one reason behind overdiagnosis is the constant advance of technology with newer more sensitive tests being developed among the latest advances in medicine is the posibility of using the masive amount of data we generate every day to find clues that might point to undiagnosed diseases throughout our day we use smartphones type emails interact on social media and count our steps on our smartwatches using artificial inteligence the data can be used to find paterns that might help us detect diseases at an earlier stage the colection and use of medical data raise ethical concerns like those of privacy and data security nonetheles this is very exciting time and many benefits wil probably emerge from these technologies but just as with traditional diagnostic methods overdiagnosis is stil risk that should be adresed so what can we do in our recently published paper we propose using data banks of longitudinal patient information data colected over long periods of time to analyse the historical trajectories of diferent diseases and identify those subgroups of patients who won be significantly afected if at al by given disease this data driven aproach could be used to improve disease definitions considering patient trajectories and identify the clinical atributes that might in the future alow clinicians to more acurately distinguish diagnosis from an overdiagnosis in pilot study we conducted using us hospital database with hundreds of thousands of hospital admisions we trained an artificial inteligence algorithm to predict which patients were likely to develop sepsis in the next hours sepsis is complication of an infection in which the body own imune response begins to damage tisues and organs we then loked at the patients flaged by the algorithm who actualy went on to develop sepsis based on oficial diagnostic criteria among them we found that almost per cent of them had trajectories that apeared to be identical to those who never went on to develop sepsis this sugests that we ned more work on defining what is and what isn sepsis the huge amounts of data that technology alows us to colect and analyse is an oportunity to beter identify people early who ned treatment before they become sick but we also ned to use big data to ensure we aren taking perfectly wel people and turning them into sick patients baner gety images futurists tel us we are on the brink of fourth industrial revolution this one is al about the digital and technological disruption of how we used to do things previous industrial revolutions saw many blue colar manufacturing jobs replaced by machines or disapear overseas to low labour cost countries developed economies like australia sucesfuly transitioned their labour force to white colar service jobs now these jobs are themselves under threat and the financial services sector is not imune many transactional services are moving online or are being replaced by ofshore cal centres and increasingly by virtual services robots or artificial inteligence systems yet the finance sector has also embraced and thrived on the oportunities created by digital disruption the traditional banking sector in particular is constantly chalenged by new nimble and highly competitive operators and must either change the tune of its service provision or face comercial oblivion the finance sector has in fact ben remarkably resilient to change in the ongoing capitalist batle of creative destruction financial institutions sem to have had markedly greater longevity than manufacturing corporations that could be explained by sustained lack of competition but it may also reflect an ability to adapt to new circumstances and adopt new technology like atms and internet banking whenever and wherever they arise there is no ned for the financial establishment to significantly invest in research and development itself banking corporations have adopted similar strategy to big pharmaceuticals let independent niche operators inovate and create start ups and ventures and when they suced simply buy them for example the sucesful australian upstarts specialising in low cost mortgage lending ausie and rams were eventualy bought by the traditional banks cba and westpac respectively the sector resilience is not just due to an ability to cope remarkably wel with external presure finance has become increasingly inovative and continuously reinvents itself to reduce the costs of regulation as wel as the delivery of beter products and services for customers regulators and legislators often strugle to kep pace with the latest developments in investment asets financial advice and risk management that often leaves new providers operating in regulatory vacum that only gets filed once things have gone teribly wrong or once lobying presure by the sector itself becomes to strong to ignore the cost of unregulated inovation on the public could be significant consider for example the fact that financial inovations like portfolio insurance and colateralised debt obligations contributed to the stock market crash and the global financial crisis respectively rather than wait for legislation and regulation to catch up we should therefore ask ourselves whether the ethics underpining these inovations pas the morality test digital technology wil arguably improve market aces for new niche financial institutions as wel as competition and make markets and services more eficient robot trading and advice can significantly reduce fes improve transparency and make financial services more acesible there is even sugestion that robot finance wil democratise the sector and lead to more just and fair financial system for al human foibles and manifestations of conflicts of interest can simply be switched of taking out human interaction could transform posibly imoral finance sector to an entirely amoral one where moral considerations simply have no role to play unfortunately this dehumanisation of finance raises its own ethical concerns as finance sector legislation regulation often significantly lags developments and practices how can we be sure that financial entrepreneurs even consider the ethical implications of their new busines models after al financial institutions often inovate to reduce the cost of regulation on conducting financial transactions these concerns extend from breaches of client information privacy to more generaly neglect of duty to clients perhaps surprisingly they sem to have increased with the introduction of digital technology service platforms while the platforms are notionaly neutral they don recognise client financial sophistication or lack thereof this digital revolution is rapidly replacing physical markets and bank branches and employes with online platforms and smartphone technology even the world of financial advice which is stil clinging to face to face transactions might wel be replaced by robot advice in the near future the platforms are cheap to develop easy to implement and efectively marketed this creates an entirely new competitive landscape with start ups and smal players specialising in specific services instantly becoming competitive entrants whereas regulators used to impose the same regimes on incumbents and newcomers who were thereby disadvantaged they now sem to provide regulatory exception to new initiatives public distrust of the finance sector has weakened the lobying power of the incumbents and convinced the regulators to encourage inovation and competition by newcomers the price paid however is posibly unchecked unethical behaviour by the inovators this is an edited extract from mater of trust the practice of ethics in finance by paul kofman and clare payne published by melbourne university pres more information is available here baner image gety images minute read in recent webinar panelists discused how the aplication of technology can adres critical ecological and urban design isues like adapting cities to climate change modern city planing neds great deal of data big problems like adapting our cities to the impacts of climate change require complex solutions digital technologies help urban designers pol diferent sources of data and consider their problems using systems thinking rather than aproaching them one project at time in our recent infrastructure webinar integrated design for resilient urban landscapes four panelists in conversation with city of melbourne mark alan discused how the aplication of technology can adres critical ecological and urban design isues watch webinar chief among the digital tols to tackle complex urban design isues are urban digital twins digital twin is virtual representation of the built and natural environment of cities the living entities with them and the proceses that make cities tick like transport networks there are thre main components in an urban digital twin said panelist dr soheil sabri senior research felow in urban analytics at the university of melbourne dr sabri managed the fishermans bend digital twin project the first urban digital twin component is the real world the second is the digital world where real world objects and proceses are represented the third is the underpining technology that conects the real world to the digital world and enables synchronisation betwen the two why are they useful an urban environment is complex dynamic environment where housing environment transport and many other factors work together any time you make change to one you re afecting al eight or nine other systems that are at work on the strets and in our public realm said panelist dr nano langenheim lecturer in landscape architecture and urban design at the university of melbourne urban designers can use digital twins to plug in data from several diferent sources to understand how these systems interact where relevant data is available in open data resources urban planing projects could save time and money however researchers and planers often colect data for specific purpose data colected for understanding the fre flow of trafic while representing the same strets may not have the information another researcher neds about fotpath quality what we are seing through digital transformation is certainly presure on maturity in the marketplace for understanding what the information management requirements are at the end of the project said panelist mr james barow mixed reality and digital enginering lead at ghd god data management standards that help define the type acuracy curency and purpose of data colected can ensure its longevity and that longevity starts with curiosity about what other users neds are mr barow explained ensurin the usability of data beyond single project increases its value city planers are already tackling the impacts of climate change increased rainfal rising sea levels and increasing temperatures the city of melbourne is using digital technologies and data in projects like increasing tre canopy cover and understanding the microclimates around the city to combat the efects of extreme heat events heat is in fact more dangerous kiler of people in australia than any other natural hazard said ms tifany crawford co chief heat oficer at the city of melbourne but she believes the solutions to climate change are available what it now requires is diferent thinking inovation and partnership think that the great minds watching this and present today are big part of that kep going ms crawford said learn more about infrastructure research first published on january technology continues to transform the practices of every organisation around the world but if we lok specificaly at the legal profesion these digital transformations can bring unanticipated legal and ethical risks in house legal departments used to be viewed as halowed black box and although it was unclear what they did their decisions were highly regarded in recent years in house lawyers have extended out into new areas of busines like environmental social and governance where they have larger role in designing and influencing the rest of their company general counsels are now devoting more time to strategic emphasis and les time to day to day busines as janet taylor hal chief executive of the legal service provider cognia law states in house lawyers engage with the sales team or procurement department siting down with them to develop templates contracts or negotiation rules most importantly there ben major change in the deployment of technology by in house legal departments to gather data analysing this data can identify emerging trends and provide early notice of larger problems like an increase in the number of new lawsuit claims report by the corporate legal operations consortium cloc shows more than half of the participants around per cent answered that their organisation views the legal department as totaly integrated into their strategy and busines acording to only thre per cent of respondents the in house legal department provides strictly legal advice australian busineses are now at risk of significantly higher cyber atacks because of their reliance on web based aplications but when it comes to cyber threat response only per cent of companies have comprehensive cyber threat response strategy that involves their legal departments cyber breaches can result not only in significant financial los but also in reputational damage so the intervention of competent legal team can mitigate those risks as an example of one of these privacy breaches human rights watch hrw has acused adobe conect aplication and minecraft education edition of violating their privacy policies and colecting children personal data for non educational purposes this highlights the ned for in house lawyers with extensive understanding of technology who are able to predict potential legal breaches and guide their employers throughout the early stages of new technology development australia privacy act curently under review is out of date in the digital age while legislators atempt to amend and suplement the relevant legislation to become more adaptable to technological change lawyers continue to face legal chalenges related to evolving digitalisation and it hard to say if these adaptions of the law realy go far enough recently consumer group choice investigated whether australian retailers kmart bunings and the god guys were violating the privacy act by using facial recognition technology to capture and colect faceprint of customers who entered selected stores around per cent of consumers were unaware that busineses used video cameras for this purpose stores using facial recognition technology in this way is similar to gathering your fingerprints or dna every time you shop under the privacy act biometric data gathered by facial recognition technology is considered sensitive personal data clearly existing laws are lacking when it comes to protecting us from potentialy harmful facial recognition technology in these cases it not clear whether the decision to deploy this technology wasn run past the legal teams in their respective organisations whether the legal teams under estimated the potential public backlash or if they didn have suficient understanding of the nuances of facial recognition to realise the potential risks or perhaps some combination of al thre in any case having tighter involvement with beter informed legal team may have raised concerns earlier or led to these organisations informing their customers in more transparent way it is very important to understand and examine how in house lawyers become involved in procuring designing deploying and overseing the emerging digital technologies in their firms and how they mitigate risks asociated with emerging technologies what is unclear is whether curent legal education and training is suficient for lawyers providing advice on emerging technology firstly for many new aplications of emerging technology there may be several areas of existing legislation that aply but most of these were designed without these technological advances in mind secondly often no precedent exists for many isues regarding emerging technology and this puts lawyers in position of neding to understand the implications of emerging technology and provide legal and ethical advice without clear legislation and precedents only once lawyers and law students understand the underlying legal and technical frameworks of emerging digital technology and are wel equiped to respond to technology related isues wil they be able to mitigate the legal risks asociated with them the centre for ai and digital ethics caide is launching new project to ensure that lawyers understand the underlying legal and technical frameworks of emerging digital technology the four year project new legal thinking for emerging technologies is funded by the menzies foundation under the ninian stephen law program the first phase is to understand how lawyers curently adres these problems if you are an in house lawyer who has given legal or ethical advice on technology we invite you for one hour online interview please contact dr university moves though its digital transformation they provide fre training fre consultancy and help your team to deploy new technologies you can read more about oxford competency centres the programe manager for the shared infrastructure services programe is brendan donely the programe wil be delivering on the work of the it infrastructure services review and wil facilitate more conected and colaborative it infrastructure acros the university work has begun to consult with coleagues acros the divisions to determine priorities for this academic year based on the initiatives from the service review the programe wil lok to define what shared service is then find and create those services and suport them with members acros the divisions further comunications wil folow during the next few weks and months the data programe manager is alex gray this programe wil implement the new data strategy which aims to improve data governance through improved proceses and technology and make that data more easily available through improved bi reporting signposting to reports and aces to data via integration these improvements suport other digital transformation and it projects university strategic initiatives such as profesional service reviews and value for money review and reduce burden on staf we asked profesor sir nigel shadbolt for his views on oxford and ai nigel is principal of jesus colege profesorial research felow and head of human centred computing in computer science university of oxford email so required the new framework wil create greater alignment to university priorities simplify and sped up decision making and put more emphasis on user focused digital experiences it wil also provide clearer view acros the institution of what digital services are available to staf and students and at what cost as part of the foundation phase of oxford university digital transformation programe we identified that one of the most important suces criteria for sustained and real impact of any digital changes is the governance and delivery of digital services and infrastructure acordingly working group was set up to consider the existing it governance and options for the future folowing its review the group has made recomendations on digital governance how we decide what to do operations how we do it and on organisational structures how we structure the organisation to operate efectively the review found that the way the university governs it is to narowly focused on just the it part and not the busines part the proposed governance framework shifts the focus from it technology to governance embeded more in the university mision and busines and extends the scope to include data information and cybersecurity the review of our existing it governance aproach found several themes including silos there are to many comites operating in silos siloed and slower decision making project based funding not efectively tensioned against other neds not suficiently tied into university priorities the comites lack integration with busines in terms of strategic input and alignment with strategic ned prioritisation and implementation curent it board model is not working apropriately portfolio scrutiny group key decision making body not enough user focus user design not embeded in projects suficiently early insuficient engagement with divisional structures not enough focus on data data governance is floating in our governance touched on in various comites focused on in none complexity the joint subcomites model does not interact efectively with other university comites to ensure strategy priorities driven by busines ned it comite is not properly pluged into our governance in general does not lead to proces simplification doesn enable service improvement model not enough focus on cybersecurity prioritisation of cybersecurity investments is not properly oversen or considered it is considered by jisag which reports into security subcomite but we ned clearer focus on cybersecurity services lack of continuity and consistency staf engaged in project delivery may be moved to deliver in other areas without the knowledge of the asociated subcomite over time the portfolio comites wil overse the delivery of services through service streams with responsible owners for the management of the service streams and service stream delivery teams who wil maintain and improve the services in time for mt new information and digital comite idc wil replace the existing it comite the idc wil be responsible for strategy and policy related to digital services and infrastructure data information and cybersecurity five portfolio comites wil be created that report to idc they are responsible for services in the areas of education research engagement and disemination administration and technology the new comite structure wil be put in place to begin from mt portfolio has two modes governance and delivery this mode includes overseing aproving monitoring governing tracking deciding and guiding projects services and spend al portfolios wil transition to the new governance model from mt new way of delivering projects and services by bringing resources teams together into delivery groups for the particular portfolio over time this wil help to depen the expertise and knowledge of coleagues working within particular portfolio the new operating model wil be piloted with the education portfolio in mt the other portfolio comites wil focus only on governance and not delivery at this this time this wil require identifying the portfolio suport and service stream owners and providing guidance training and suport as we work through the implementation of the new model at the same time key asets wil ned to be created that wil be required by the comites and teams review of the pilot wil be completed in trinity term which wil inform the further development of the remaining portfolios the new digital governance framework provides clearer view acros the institution of what digital services are available to staf and students and at what cost at present this information is not available and sits in many budget lines acros the institution the aim of the proposed changes to governance and the operating model are to shift the delivery of services to be more closely aligned with the busines strategy and user neds the change to the funding and delivery model has ben made to alow more agile and continuous improvement aproach and to move away from our existing project driven way of working the model is based on service stream delivery teams which wil alow us to build experienced teams knowledgeable in both the busines ned and digital capabilities most importantly this aims to reduce siloed decision making proces whilst at the same time increasing the capability to prioritise spend efectively the digital transformation programe team wil continue to exist and wil suport delivery of the programe during this transition period dedicated change management team wil overse the seting up of the portfolios the creation of the asets to suport the portfolios providing the training and suport for the comites asisting in provision of training for service stream owners and in the specific case of he education portfolio suporting the service stream delivery teams as wel the change management team wil also be responsible for the delivery in due course of the changes recomended by the it infrastructure service review we recognise that there wil be significant period of transition to bed in the new governance project and service delivery identifying and responding to skil gaps and potentialy implementing organisational change to suport service and new governance delivery the ful implementation of the governance framework and operating model is expected to take at least months and posibly as long as months this may apear to be slow transition but the sugested timing takes into acount the potential organisational operational changes that wil be the outcome of the it infrastructure service review and the continuing series of activities within the digital transformation programe the implementation of the new governance framework and operating model are transformative in how we envisage digital services and infrastructure and how they are integrated into planing and embeded to ensure the institution is digitaly fit for the future once this transition is complete which may take up to two years the digital transformation programe becomes busines as usual and the programe team can be disbanded if you have any questions or concerns please speak with your existing comite chair or line manager or you can email the programe team at email so required ugr experts websites universidad de granada about news acesibility ugres gets score out ranking acesibility acesibility of ugr es gets score of out of in the ranking of acesibility of university websites the main website of the ugr improves its acesibility and achieves score of out of in the ranking that analyses the acesibility of university websites the website rises to sixth position out of the institutions analysed the main website of the university of granada has ben progresively improving its acesibility in the last period and this has ben recognised in the report prepared by the web acesibility observatory of the ministry of economic afairs and digital transformation this analysis has determined that the main website of en qué puedo ayudarte the university of granada ranks sixth among the spanish university websites considered without taking into acount the complexity of the website and seventh among those the acesibility of ugr es gets score of out of in the ranking of acesibility of university websites universidad de granada government websites considered of high complexity in this report the acesibility of the ugr website is rated with score of out of the report caried out by the web acesibility observatory analyses sample of the pages contained in the ugr website establishing what type of pages should apear in the sample given the imposibility of analysing the hundreds or thousands of pages that can form part of the websites of this type of institutions thus the home page the legal conditions page the contact page and series of randomly selected pages of diferent types were analysed the university of granada through the acesibility unit ura which reports to the rector ofice for the digital university has made continuous efort to adapt its website to acesibility standards so that the information published is acesible and available to everyone the acesibility of website is esential to ensure that it can be acesed for example by people using diferent types of devices with diferent characteristics in terms of size and quality to aces information people with temporary disabilities such as temporary vision or mobility problems age related problems or people with slow internet conection or with specific aces problems an acesible website should among other features use an apropriate font size and colour contrast have coherent structure and each page should be wel organised web acesibility is achieved through the use of apropriate technologies but it also depends on the acesibility of the contents introduced by th users of the diferent websites to raise awarenes and train these users web acesibility courses are held periodicaly for ugr employes on september most of the provisions of the new royal decre of september on acesibility of public sector websites and aplications for mobile devices came into force which transposes into spanish law the directive eu of the european parliament and of the council of october on the acesibility of websites and aplications for mobile devices of public sector bodies this royal decre obliges al websites of public entities to comply with the web content acesibility guidelines wcag this regulation establishes series of considerations that must be taken into acount for website to be acesible and therefore for any person regardles of their limitations to be able to consult the information contained on the website in adition al public entities are obliged to creat an aucéc epsusiebdilioty uyundita retsep onsible for ensuring compliance with legal regulations and promoting acesibility among other functions the acesibility of ugr es gets score of out of in the ranking of acesibility of university websites universidad de granada you can find more information about web acesibility on acesibility terms of use and privacy rs news site map universidad de granada folow us on social media en qué puedo ayudarte science city and change exhibition launches at the ugr universidad de granada about news science city and change exhibition launches ugr science city and change exhibition launches at the ugr university news events the science city and change exhibition wil oficialy launch today february at the hospital real the seat of the rectorate of the university of granada the exhibition explores the pivotal role played by science and scientific institutions led by the ugr as drivers of change in the city since the mid th century it also examines how these changes have afected the lives of granada citizens the exhibition aims to provide visitors with cros sectional perspectives on how the city has evolved and become what it is today proceses that would be imposible to understand without examining the role of science and the university it features over pieces from the ugr extensive heritage colections including the wel known zambrano pharmacy as wel as pieces from local institutions and private colections four audiovisual works one of which is imersive wil also be on display the exhibition comprises five sections the first transformation of the urban and social space reflects on the expansion of the urban fabric of the city over the past sixty years largely owing to the development of new spaces for the generation and disemination of knowledge heritage and urban interweaving takes stock of how we value the city heritage and how the university is perceived in granada the starting point of this section is the important work undertaken by the ugr since the of recovering restoring and conserving granada urban heritage it also highlights the ugr eforts to enhance the value placed on this heritage from the lecture hal to the laboratory reflects on the ways in which teaching research and the comunication of science have ben transformed in granada by turning laboratories science city and change exhibition launches at the ugr universidad de granada into the focal point of teaching activities predominantly bok based aproach was surpased giving rise to laboratory culture that required sophisticated and costly scientific instrumentation this section continues by loking towards siera nevada as the great laboratory of the city population and economy loks at the development of the city hospitals and the impact that healthcare services have had on the daily lives of citizens the final section entitled from the study rom to the digital library is housed in the university library it focuses on the changes that neded to be introduced in order to met the new demands of the information age it also reflects on the new scientific cultural and social tasks performed by this key service which extends beyond the scope of th university comunity itself granada city of science and inovation science city and change aims to ilustrate the crucial role played by scientific institutions in knowledge generation and in the transformation of granada as wel as its suroundings over the past years it is hoped that this endeavour wil further contribute to the anxiously awaited designation of granada as the european capital of culture an advent that would coincide with the year aniversary since the founding of the ugr pres conference was held on tuesday february to promote the exhibition with speches by the rector pilar aranda the ugr profesor of history of medicine and curator of the exhibition alfredo menéndez and the vice rector for outreach víctor medina the science city and change exhibition wil oficialy open at on february in the crucero bajo exhibition space at the hospital real it wil be on display until may opening hours monday to friday and saturday and sunday further information science city and change science city and change exhibition launches at the ugr universidad de granada share this news jan dec what to do if you have exams but may instructions on evaluation for covid have covid isues during final asesment exercises in the st semester science city and change exhibition launches at the ugr universidad de granada feb dec comuniqué of on teaching protocol for covid isues during final activities at the begining of the second exams in the first semester of semester featured links acesibility terms of to your comunity strengthen my knowledge and get to know beautiful places and wonderful people sumary and abstract ix sumary development of digital transformation model of geographic data through of information and comunications technologies icts use case cartography and geological and geomorphological research group of the colombian geological service sgc curently information and comunications technologies icts are imersed in broad technological social and economic context that has enhanced their use in research proceses and in the development of digital transformation projects is esential therefore for organizations to improve methods work flows manage data and automate proceses through the implementation of solutions based on digital technologies on the other hand there is growing use in geographic data organizations in their misional proceses and lack of guidelines and instruments that guide intervention for this type of data in terms of digital transformation responding to this lack the contribution of this research is the development of digital transformation model for geographic data through icts in case of study was the cartography and geological and geomorphological research group of the sgc the model which has ben caled geo td is based on the characterization and prioritization of proceses by calculating the level of digital maturity in dimensions people and digital culture digital data and analytics digital proceses and technology in adition encompases the architectural metamodel that drives the definition of components technological for the design and construction of the validation technological platform geo td centralizes geographic data in one system avoids duplication of records makes beter use of storage resources eliminates the use of local files and alows consult historical works without wasting efort and resources geo td is also replicable model that can adapt to any scenario that handles data geographical keywords geographic data digital transformation icts gis architecture solution reference architecture digital maturity technological platform development of digital transformation model of geographic data through information and comunications technologies ict abstract development of digital transformation model for geographic data through information and comunication technologies icts case study cartography and geological and geomorphological research group of the colombian geological service sgc curently in formation and comunications technologies icts are imersed in broad technological social and economic context that has enhanced their use in research proceses and in the development of digital transformation projects it is therefore esential for organizations to improve methods workflows manage data and automate proceses through the implementation of digital technology based solutions on the other hand there is growing use of geographic data in mision proceses in organizations and there is lack of guidelines and tols to guide intervention for this type of data in the field of digital transformation in response to this lack the contribution of this research is the development of digital transformation model for geographic data through icts the case study was the grupo de cartografía investigación geológica geomorfológica of the sgc the model which has ben caled geo td is based on the characterization and prioritization of proceses through the calculation of the level of digital maturity in dimensions people and digital culture digital data and analytics digital proceses and technology it also covers the metamodel of architecture that leads to the definition of technological components for the design and construction of the validation technology platform geo td centralizes geographic data in system avoids duplication of records makes beter use of storage resources eliminates the use of local files and alows historical work to be consulted without duplicating efort and resources geo td is also replicable model that can be adapted to any scenario that handles geographic data keywords geographic data digital transformation icts gis solution architecture introduction general context within the framework of the fourth industrial revolution hereinafter ir or industry information and comunications technologies hereinafter icts are made up of basic elements through which it is posible to strengthen the capacities and organizational competencies alowing to improve contribute propose and articulate methods ways of working inovations and technologies tota et al the ir has ben oriented towards the development of inteligent systems proces automation big data and analytics artificial inteligence hereinafter ai augmented reality modeling and virtual simulation aditive manufacturing among others becera al of them fields and technologies that capture and or manage digital data consequently solutions based on digital technologies are esential in organizations to optimize methods workflows data management perform apropriate transition from analogue proceses to more acurate digital proceses and enable ways and means so that they can be procesed by machines oecd in that sense and considering that geographic information hereinafter gi is fundamental for the cartographic representation of the teritory information science geographic it is not alien to this technological trend that apears in the curent context more like paradigmatic field that leads to the generation of specific proceses that guarante the quality of geographical data and promote its use and exploitation through icts development of digital transformation model of geographic data through of information and comunications technologies icts background the oecd oecd for its acronym organization for coperation and development economics presents within its projects the idg idg for its acronym index of digital government which measures the level of digital maturity of government strategies digital for member countries and based on the results suports the design of strong initiatives that suport digital policies and practices of ca country oecd aded to the above are the imd world digital competitivenes ranking imd for its acronym institute for management development which sets out criteria to measure the ability of an economy to adopt and explore digital technologies that lead to transformation in government practices busines models and society in general imd world competitivenes center as cited in dnp and the goverment development index which shows the state of government development electronic in the member countries of the un un for its acronym organization of the united nations dnp in relation to this eclac eclac by its acronym economic comision for the americas latin america and the caribean publishes in the report data and facts about the transformation digital in which it presents the main indicators regarding the adoption of digital technologies and exposes the curent situation in latin america and the caribean in diferent levels of technology use and development eclac the design and formulation of international criteria and indices to promote proceses of digital transformation in the regions confirms the ned to adopt policies and government strategies so that public organizations get involved proactively in the implementation and monitoring of digital technologies and alow strengthen institutional and national capacities colombia through the ministry of information and comunications technologies mintic is responding to the bariers and chalenges posed within the framework of the ir adopting and implementing the digital government policy that aims to promote the use and exploitation of information technologies and technologieschapter comunications to consolidate competitive proactive state and citizens and inovative that generate public value in an environment of digital trust mintic in that sense the colombian state through the dnp and conpes conpes for its acronym national council of economic and social policy has developed documents that reinforce and enhance the use of digital data for decision making in the apropriate proceses conpes document of policy for digital transformation and inteligence artificial establishes the conditions to enhance the generation of social and economic value through the strategic use of digital technologies and promoting artificial inteligence in the framework for taking advantage of the oportunities and chalenges of ict on the other hand document conpes of consolidation of national policy of geographic information and the icde icde for its acronym colombian infrastructure of spatial data seks to strengthen the production exchange aces and use of gi in the state entities and promote the development of the icde as mechanism for the harmonization and standardization of information geographical ation dnp in section diagnosis of the chapter of guidelines for the consolidation of the icde of conpes of it is indicated that the central problem in the management of gi in the diferent levels of the state is the disarticulation in production availability aces and use of gi which leads to the los of the gi due to the lack of aplication of software standards and tols having outdated ig and partial coverage of the teritory due to the aplication of porly structured plans and out of context strategic failures in the articulation betwen entities generating gi to develop projects in comon objective deficiency in the quality of the gi due to the low level of design and aplication of production standards documentation aces and use of the gi among others development of digital transformation model of geographic data through of information and comunications technologies icts problem formulation the colombian congres isues the national development plan pact for colombia pact for equity through law of article in which establishes state entities of the national order must incorporate into their respective action plans the digital transformation component folowing the standards defined for this purpose by the ministry of information technologies and comunications to achieve this strategic digital transformation projects must be guided by principles described in this law which sek to guarante the use and exploitation of the data infrastructure through standards models standards and tols for risk management and digital security prioritize interoperability betwen information systems and platforms for data exchange promote the use of technologies based on fre software or open source and technologies emerging ir such as dlt distributed ledger technology masive data analysis big data ai ai for its acronym artificial inteligence iot iot for its acronym internet of things robotics and similar and promoting programs of use of technologies for citizen participation and open government in proceses misions of public entities dnp in short this law determines that in al scenarios the digital transformation must incorporate the components asociated with emerging technologies defined as those of the fourth industrial revolution among others dnp under this aproach state entities have oriented their strategic plans towards modernization and digital transformation the igac igac by its acronym geographic institute agustín codazi entity in charge of producing researching regulating disposing and diseminate geographical cartographic agrological cadastral geodetic and geospace technologies them for their aplication in knowledge management proceses comprehensive planing and development of the country has presented its strategic plan of information technologies peti with the objective of generating the roadmap that suports the modernization and digital transformation of the igac in the consolidation of their capabilities to fulfil their institutional goals and objectives suported in the intensive use of icts igac chapter likewise the sgc in compliance with law of presented in the version of the peti which establishes the guiding document for projects of technology as contribution to the fulfilment of institutional objectives based on the enterprise architecture program in its second cycle sgc this document describes the actions undertaken within the aei aei for its acronym architecture institutional busines designed since through the suport of the cifi cifi for its acronym research center of the faculty of enginering of the university of the andes the aei program was divided into phases the first phase was based on the socialization of basic concepts of aei through the elaboration of the diagnosis of the situation in as is architecture and the joint generation of the situation or state desired architecture to be the main product of this phase was the preparation of the roadmap of projects grouped into major initiatives on which the sgc had to guide its eforts and strategies phase includes the prioritization of architecture domains in order to design and launch the pilot of highly scalable solution for earthquake related information and transfering apropriately the petroleum information bank bip betwen the national agency of hydrocarbons anh and the sgc finaly phase continues with the implementation of projects that alow the strengthening of information systems data and technological infrastructure at the institutional level sgc the results of cycle of the aei led to the development of technological tols web platforms information systems geoportals and geoviewers that integrate and they provide geoscientific information for internal and external users next some of them are presented the geoscientific information integration engine mig it brings together the oficial historical information in each project the bip is the oficial repository of colombia to safeguard and manage al the technical information resulting from the exploratory and hydrocarbon production activities that take place in the national teritory the mas movement information system sima alows upload manage and consult the mas movements that ocured in colombia for the comprehensive risk management teritorial and environmental planing and planing desa development the bd explora database centralizes geochemical information data for investigations and characterization of mineral resources aditionaly development of digital transformation model for geographic data through of information and comunications technologies icts during this cycle the strengthening and optimization of the infrastructure was caried out technological by adapting main data center for the operation and an alternate data center storage comunication capacity and availability solutions for data geoscientists in the developed tols sgc in the sgc updates the aei and proposes second cycle focused in data analytics for management which gathers purifies and transforms data to structured systems to describe explore and analyze information through control boards that suport monitoring folow up evaluation and control of objectives proces projects users and resources of the qms on the other hand data analytics geoscientists alows aplying multidisciplinary knowledge through proceses of analysis interpretation comunication of spatial data of diferent origin and format geostatistics and modeling and visualization so that researchers can understand explain explore and predict the characteristics and behaviors of the subsoil the potential of its resources and threats of geological origin sgc the sgc within the framework of the initiatives to contribute to the aei has structured the ide geoscientific aimed at facilitating the availability and aces to spatial information to do this it has ben based on the guidelines of the colombian data infrastructure icde of the igac which is the government strategy designed to integrate and provide geographic information that promotes the generation of value in the teritory sgc in the icde presents the results obtained from the asesment caried out on the ide sdi for its acronym spatial data infrastructure institutional of the sgc which does not it was formalized at the time of the evaluation icde the methodology was based on the execution of interviews and work tables with the qms staf in order to identify the degre of progres regarding the components organizational human resources information standards and ict services from the themes and indices defined as part of the maturity levels project of sdi the maturity level was based on the weighting of each of the components whose sum is likewise at each level in total value was defined minimum depending on the themes identified in each one finaly the study and diagnosis of the institutional ide named as geoscientific ide showed as resulted in an advanced level of maturity as product of what was presented in chapter compose organizational and information entities optimized human resources medium ict standards and services advanced icde however the icde recomends generate technical specifications for the products that are generated kep them updated standards in acordance with curent international regulations enhance the integration and systems developed to generate analysis tols continue with the enterprise architecture project strengthen internal participation in the definition of projects in adition to citizen and private company participation it is required an information government articulated with busines architecture and government digital the above recomendations are tasks the sgc has proposed to solve through some proposals and initiatives continuing with the strategies proposed by the sgc for digital transformation and management of the entity data was caried out through the cifi of the university of the andes the first evaluation of the data maturity level with the purpose of knowing the diagnosis of the qms in this regard and based on it define path for improvement in the points that are weak in the measurement uniandes the diagnosis of the maturity level of the qms showed that it is at level caled repeatable acording to the framework data management maturity dm model of the cmi institute this level is defined as the proces is suficiently developed and diferent people execute more or les the same procedures no there is no formal comunication or development of competencies and capacities of the procedures and responsibility is individual there is great dependence on knowledge that individuals have and therefore there is probability of eror important uniandes the dm data maturity model aplied is composed of questions about diferent aspects of qms data management to cary out the diagnose the curent state of data management maturity and provide guidance and recomendations of best practices to implement to achieve maturity levels superiors in data management uniandes development of digital transformation model of geographic data through of information and comunications technologies icts figure result of the data management maturity level for the qms source uniandes considering the above it is evident that the actions undertaken by the sgc in terms of digital transformation have ben constant and are framed mainly in the aei however based on previous work on the use of icts in the design and construction of digital transformation models for geographic data and their aplication in organizational environments the slr systematic literature review is means of evaluating and interpret the research available and relevant to topic or phenomenon of interest it aims to present fair evaluation of research topic using reliable rigorous and auditable methodology kitchenham charters in this research work the literature review was caried out under the criteria methodologies set out by kitchenham charters in its most recent version there models based on icts for the digital transformation of geographic data and in acordance with the proposed stages previously stage slr planing formulation of research questions acording to kitchenham tomlinson to natural resource management tomlinson since then series have emerged of events that have concluded in trends to use maps and geographic data to of taking them to implementation in computer systems that can be limited up to early when the transfer began from technology to the world wide web siabato in tim reily whom generaly credited with being the author of the term web he field of icts and to do so they consolidate the radical changes that condition the imediate future and in particular aspects related to quality and interoperability in the framework of icts table of computing to each organization in the decade from the and it could be considered first aproach to the digitization of the geographical sciences second wave with the arival of computing in every ofice in the and where geographical tasks began to be executed with computers through gis thus giving birth to geographical information sciences in this space began to be explored with simulations automatic models and high level analysis amount of data third wave with the arival of computing to every thing this stage covers the arival of the new milenium to the present the rise of computing and technology facilitated every operation in almost every aspect of life and organizational productivity with the arival of industry technologies such as iot and big data data science is remerging in an acelerated maner through of these technological findings research and studies begin to be conducted towards geographic data science in the last decade making use of new technological trends geolocation software artificial inteligence and machine learning rq what characteristics do geographic data present analog analog which have ben part of the digital transformation analog geographic data has evolved and adapted to the digital age the transition of cartography and spatial analysis from paper work to digitalization has given rise to the geodigital era buzai et al geospatial technologies such as gis and global positioning systems gps have experienced rapid advance in recent decades facilitating the analysis of geographic data in comparison with traditional analog methods services and increased research development of digital transformation model of geographic data to through information and comunications technologies icts scientist in this field for example the use of exchange and interoperability of geospatial resources chen et al the management of geographic data especialy those aditional to the standards international data such as environmental and mobility data has required and specific models such as the envisio method which has ben used in authorities environmental strategies for interdisciplinary coperation poßner et al the digital transformation in promoted citizen participation in urban planing through methods and modern geospatial tols haklay et al in the agricultural industry the use of information technologies and comunication ict for the proces relevant contributions were identified that adres the guiding questions among these contributions are various digital transformation models dtm proposed by diferent authors erol et al propose an transformation model in thre stages envision enable and enact during the envision stage we sek to develop participatory vision of involving stakeholders then in the enable stage converts the vision into concrete busines model and develops strategies for its implementation sucesful implementation finaly in the enact stage the strategies are converted into real projects on the other hand schalmo et al develop five phase roadmap for the digital transformation these phases include digital reality digital ambition potential digital adjustment and digital implementation each phase adreses diferent related aspects with value creation customer requirements best practices and integration with partners in the framework proposed by is sa et al for the implementation of in manufacturing organizations several steps are established these include the formation of working group the evaluation of digitalization the definition of aproaches the use case idea generation impact estimation and case selection of use acording to the level of maturity of the organization development of digital transformation model of geographic data to through information and comunications technologies icts romero et al present lean digital transformation framework that combines lean practices and tols in five management pilars this aproach includes management digital strategy which involves defining long term digital vision evaluating the maturity digital and select apropriate technologies and work methods le grand deneckere propose an agile change management model that consists of thre phases definition experimentation and anchoring in the definition phase diagnosis in the experimentation phase workshop and control cycles are caried out and in the anchoring phase an overview of completed and future projects is provided along with an analysis of the capacity for change ng et al define conceptual model for the systematic development of planing plans digitalization action in companies this model includes stages such as the evaluation of the curent busines model the design of the digital busines model the evaluation of the curent digital capabilities the identification of future digital capabilities and the development of the action plan rautenbach et al propose conceptual model of digital transformation in two phases evaluation of the curent value creation proces and internal and external evaluation of the organization these asesments lead to the creation of job creation profiles value and digital profiles which guide the organization in creating value by taking advantage the digital dimension pesl et al propose model to evaluate the digital maturity of companies and develop an action plan its focus is on bridging the gap betwen the state curent and objective state of digital transformation this idea is directly related with the methodological framework proposed by leone barni who sugest suporting smes in their digital transformation by identifying inovation gaps and converting them in integration projects its aproach seks to help companies with resources limited to achieving sucesful transformation on the other hand but proposes framework based on the busines proces tradition management bpm to optimize busines proceses during transformation digital their focus is on redesigning proceses to adapt to the digital age this idea is also related to the conceptual framework presented by van tonder et al chapter who es highlight the importance of inovation in the busines model during the digital transformation both aproaches sek to ensure that the proceses and model busines are aligned with the organization digital objectives regarding the integration of social technologies and iot mendhurwar mishra highlight its importance in digital transformation but also point out the chalenges of asociated security and privacy this idea coincides with the proposal of nikitin kulchytsky who propose digital transformation management model based on the strategic relationship betwen government society companies and software developers both aproaches consider the ethical and security as key elements during the digital transformation proces finaly ou et al present specific decision making framework for the digital transformation in the retail industry its focus is on identifying busines problems set goals and execute transformation plan this idea highlights the importance of strategic planing and proper execution during the digital transformation proces in general these theories and aproaches converge on the importance of evaluating and colaboration betwen diferent actors to achieve sucesful transformation these main ideas provide solid foundation to adres the chalenges and take advantage of the oportunities that arise in the environment mintic in the curent context of technological bom and the arival of industry technologies emerging technologies known as emerging icts are emerging rapidly is it is important to note that steps in each of them them mintic these stages are the folowing yo understand and create strategies to develop ict implementation strategies based on objectives of the entity identify posible aplications of icts verify the feasibility of the implementation design to establish prerequisites and evaluate the curent state of the entity develop pilot test enable to enable the necesary
