aplied in measuring the maturity of the digital transformation aligning the model organization for its digital future the objective of this chapter is to describe on the one hand the maturity model of digital transformation mtd selected and on the other the setings made for its subsequent aplication in the organization under study therefore the chapter has section in which the dimensions are presented maturity levels and questionaire structure of the selected mtd section showing the adjustment made to the mtd selected to aply and section with the chapter sumary digital transformation maturity model aligning the organization for its digital future to understand the chalenges and oportunities asociated with using social busines and digital mit sloan management review in colaboration with deloite developed anual survey of executives managers and busines analysts from organizations acros the world which gave way to mtd aligning the organization for its digital future by kane et al focused on carying out measurements such as digital maturity level of the organization anticipate the interuption prepare adequately the bigest threat your company faces as result of the digital trend percentage of profesionals who want to leave their organization in les than year given digital trends most important technology for the organization today analysis of the degre of maturity of the digital transformation of an organization ion the organization digital strategy is early developing or mature percentage of respondents who agre strongly agre rating of the company culture on scale of to how companies strengthen their digital inovation capabilities most important skil an organizational leader must have to be sucesful in digital workplace talent neds vs atraction capacity dimensions of digital transformation maturity to navigate the complexity of digital busines companies must adopt the that kane et al caled digital congruence culture people structure and tasks aligned with each other so that executives can efectively adres the chalenges of constantly changing digital landscape culture acept risk geting an organization to acept risk goes beyond warnings that taking risks is aceptable organizations that mature digitaly incorporate risk taking into the fabric of how they manage kane et al people depening the company skils companies that mature digitaly are more than five times more likely to provide employes with oportunities to develop digital skils necesary than early stage companies early stage companies on the contrary they depend on consultants and contractors although this may be means excelent at suporting eforts from the begining relying solely on help external should only be provisional measure kane et al the talent shortage wil continue to grow and employes and executives who do not fel those who acquire digital skils wil lok for this elsewhere therefore the digitaly maturing organizations do more than ofer training courses with the increasing presure to perform and the acelerated pace of change brought about by digital technology the most powerful way to learn is not to aces what others people already know but rather encourage the creation of new knowledge through chapter practice in the workplace itself rather than in training rom kane et al figure digital congruence digital transformation maturity dimensions source taken from kane et al structure adaptive and agile hierarchical leadership structures were designed for complex organizations in more stable times to become more agile and foster colaboration some large organizations simplify their structures and turn to cros functional teams to become more agile and let formal structures fade into background or disapear completely this is acompanied by the fact that leaders can establish high level guidelines that can then be aplied by local units and functions to adapt ideas to your problems more and neds kane et al tasks contingent workforces and customized work the complex and lengthy selection and background check proceses permanent and temporary jobs wil not be able to kep up with al the neds of talent in rapidly changing environments often the best talent is not located within the four wals of an organization and not everyone loks for fixes analysis of the degre of maturity of the digital transformation of an organization traditional employment growing field of companies are adapting to these trends and provide aces to selected independent talent who are acesed as service that conects and plays with the work of the organization and the hiring proceses kane et al the chalenge is having the right person with the right skils in the right place at the apropriate time that alows the efectivenes of the organization here they come to play factors of work organization in acordance with the capabilities of the company which met your specific neds suported by suitable human talent and eliminating unecesary activities within proceses and procedures kane et al strategy leading into the future evolving to compete in an increasingly digital world is not just about implement more and beter technologies it involves aligning the company organization with the demands of the digital environment by increasing risk apetite investing in digital oportunities for your employes optimize organizational structures to achieve agility and rethink how and by whom work is done only when these factors organizational organizations come together the company can go from being digital to being transformed digitaly however since these factors are not aligned the eforts of digitalization can do litle to improve company ability to compete in digital world even if the technology investment and implementation are corect kane et al nadler tushman spearheaded the idea of organizational congruence as main ingredient for optimal corporate performance the concept is that only when the esential components of busines its culture people structure and tasks are closely aligned the company can achieve powerful results kane et al in an ever changing digital landscape the concept of congruence takes on new meaning and relevance since many companies do not they ensure that al elements of the organization work together over time as much as posible that does not favor the integration of your digital strategy with that of the busines chapter digital transformation maturity levels kane et al defined thre levels of digital transformation maturity early developing and maturing with based on scale of rating from to in which it is evaluated that both the company is considered as ideal organization transformed by digital technologies and capabilities that improve proceses atract talent acros the organization and drive new busines models that generate value where not close means that the study company is not for nothing or very litle similar to this ideal organization and very close that the company study is very similar or equal to this ideal organization se figure in more detail about the maturity levels for this model it is considered that the digitaly maturing companies closely link their digital strategies with the overal strategy of their company and also have longer term vision of strategy compared to early stage companies kane et al regarding culture there are thre diferent mentalities that are closely related with the stages of digital maturity the first mentality is comon among early stage digital organizations and is characterized by low apetite for risk hierarchical leadership structure work done in silos and decisions based more in instinct than in data on the contrary the cultural mentalities that relate closely to companies that mature digitaly value the experimentation and sped acept risk and create leadership structures distributed aditionaly they encourage colaboration and are more likely to use data in the decision making in the midle are the cultures on the way from the first group to the third kane et al talent development is an important element of the culture in organizations that mature digitaly who place decisive emphasis on developing existing talent and recruit new talent while early stage companies are more likely to resort to contractors and consultants kane et al companies that mature digitaly are significantly more capable of atracting new talent based on their use of digital in contrast to early stage organizations which tend to rely on external parties to suport your digital eforts as result it generates talent gap for early stage companies although these companies ned digital talent to help them advance digitaly their lack of progres restricts their ability to atract that talent kane et al analysis of the degre of maturity of the digital transformation of an organization figure digital transformation maturity levels source own elaboration adapted from kane et al digitaly maturing organizations provide the resources and oportunities so your employes thrive in digital environment by developing employes for the suces in digital environments busines leaders are placing more emphasis on skils of change than in technological knowledge kane et al digitaly maturing companies also value leadership knowledge technology is not the most important skil that leaders must have the ability to leading company through busines model change is the most important and being forward thinking progresive is almost as important with clear vision solid strategy and foresight acording to kane et al structure of the maturity comunications have ben become tol par excelence to improve public management and state citizen relationship and under this guideline the entity acts in this dimension for the mtd organizations that conclusions the objective of this final master thesis was to analyze the degre of maturity of the digital transformation of an organization which was achieved by characterizing the methods models for measuring the maturity of digital transformation based on review of systematic literature that gave way to the description of maturity models for after the execution of the selection proces define an ideal mtd to aply in the organization under study as result of this selection the maturity model was chosen aligning the organization for its digital future by kane et al this mtd was adapted to latin american spanish and adjusted in terms of terminology and number of demographic clasification and characterization questions which resulted in survey with total of questions that received the name survey to digital busines executives aligning the organization for its digital future by aplying the method or model for measuring the maturity of the digital transformation more suitable for the organization with participation of of the target population and places to the organization at level of maturity of the digital transformation in development finding itself in the transition from traditional organizational structure to one that acepts more risk encourages colaboration is more likely to use data in decision making decisions works to closely link its digital strategies with the strategy general of his company with long term vision he strives to develop talent existing and recruit new talent based on their use of digital has begun to provide the resources and oportunities for your employes to thrive in digital environment and its institutional leaders begin to pay atention to the change skils despite this even the entity under study must make eforts to corect the existing gaps to be an ideal organization transformed by technologies and digital capabilities that improve proceses atract talent throughout the organization and promote new busines models that generate value what led to propósito analysis of the degre of maturity of the digital transformation of an organization recomendations to the organization to improve its level of transformation maturity digital based on aplication results based on curent state analysis and the ideal state for each dimension of the mtd the gap analysis the documentary analysis and the interviews caried out with the representative in td of the organization are tols used to complement the colection of information obtained from the aplication of the mtd give the model the functionality of being prescriptive and generate roadmap that helps the organization under study to improve your degre of progres in digital transformation aditionaly it was proposed improvement for the mtd in which the questions of its questionaire were grouped acording to the dimensions it proposes to facilitate the analysis of results and generation of recomendations among the key recomendations the definition of an apropriate digital strategy stands out to the strategic planing of the organization under study and its subsequent socialization to ensure its apropriation by al colaborators of the entity the design implementation and maintenance of an enterprise architecture and the monitoring and updating of the organization petic since based on this moves the organization digital transformation vision and its guidelines are derived in terms of digital strategy it is very necesary that the organization where the selected mtd was aplied conceives its digital transformation proces as an extension of your strategic planing aligned with the digital government policy through decre of mintic national development plan colombia world power of life dnp as observed in the gap analysis the lack in the rom ility and knowledge of its oficials to implement the digital strategy this exposed to risks that management faces by not focusing on achievable goals and the eficient use of its resources by covering more than what alows achieving the management capacity and even more so in digital transformation the organization also has late decision making and its planing is is not adaptive which slows down your digital transformation proces by not considering the technology and data as strategic factor for the entity that generates value in the lack of comprehensive cordination betwen operational strategic and misional areas that gives results in it management and where finaly the information is not beingconclusions timely reliable available and is not at al times at the service of the users in acordance with its transparency and integrity criteria however as great strength of the entity the interest of its talent is presented human being to learn new knowledge and acquire new skils that enable them be efective in your digital environment for the improvement of your organization on the other hand it is concluded that preparing for digital future is not an easy task means develop digital capabilities in which activities people culture and structure of company are synchronized and aligned with set of objectives organizational however most companies are limited by the lack of resources lack of talent and the pul of other priorities leaving executives in charge of managing digital initiatives that take the form of projects or are limited to activities within given division function or activity or chanel in world increasingly digital digital transformation is not just about implementing more and beter technologies implies digital congruence aligning culture people structure and tasks of the organization the scope of the proposed objectives was achieved by executing the descriptive study established since it was aimed at measuring the presence characteristics or distribution of the maturity of the digital transformation in the organization under study limiting to describe one or several phenomena without the intention of establishing causal relationships with other factors and without intentional manipulation only the phenomena were observed as they were as they ocured in their natural context with the combination of quantitative techniques and qualitative tests to obtain the required information which ofered an idea of the level of maturity of digital transformation but as is evident it is not generalizable to al entities in the sector and does not generalize the situation of the organization object of study likewise the mtd aligning the organization for its digital future by kane et al provides comprehensive overview how digital transformation ocurs within company from its strategy culture human talent structure and tasks as wel as the posibility of delimiting its objective state by defining what the conditions are of company in digital maturation analysis of the degre of maturity of the digital transformation of an organization limitations in the development of this degre work there was limitation regarding aces to the implemented methods of various digital transformation maturity models mtd to measure the maturity of organizations in terms of digital transformation although maturity measurement models were obtained in the rsl very few presented complete information for implementation only of mtd had this information aditionaly the maturity model of selected digital transformation was only aplied to one organization due to that aces to these is restricted and we worked with non probabilistic sample for convenience of single case regarding the aplication within the organization under study it was also stated lack of interest on the part of your colaborators towards the oportunity to improve their degre of suces in digital transformation having reduced participation of which does not provide the posibility of an online survey was adopted as method for this research because it alowed rapid distribution cycles and response as wel as automatic verification and response capture in databases the survey was based on questionaire designed originaly by wendler which in turn was based on exhaustive review of the literature and its purpose was to generate understanding organizational agility in specific industry from comprehensive perspective and global vision it was administered to general and it related decision makers such as executive directors executives technology directors managers and employes in leadership positions in industry organizations software and it services around the world the questionaire was carefuly pre tested by academics and profesionals and finaly composed of questions the survey of organizational agility maturity of the ins because important objective was to evaluate the perceptions among the entire personel regardles of the clasification level the questions of the survey were asigned to two separate questionaires managers and general staf for purposes of granularity in terms of evaluation of the survey results the study team first grouped the questions acording to each of the six dimensions and then the clasified by subthemes which were based on what wendler caled agility concepts the questions were asked in five point likert scale based on the original survey both surveys used behavioral aproach whereby observable behavior was measured instead of asking about the subjective beliefs of an individual observations the study presents the maturity product and service development production logisticsanex mtd characterization shets mtd characterization shet marketing and sales indicators method the methodology used in this study folows protocols of research clasification and bibliometric analysis curently several databases use indicators bibliometric and provide bibliometric analysis of the scientific production the data presented in this study were obtained through bibliometric research of these two platforms this bibliometric study analyzed total of publications in the web of science and the elsevier scopus platform initialy the terms industry advanced manufacturing and digital transformation were combined with the term maturity to identify scientific publications ranging from to total of publications were identified the analysis of these publications shows drastic increase in scientific publications in with germany and brazil one of the main contributors of the publications twelve introduced maturity model for industry aditionaly four more practice oriented publications covering maturity models for more detailed analysis these maturity models evaluate the maturity of company on regarding industry based on diferent enablers and technological dimensions of company they do not point to maturity as dimension in itself observations the article does not present the complete guide for the calculation of of studies examining dimensions metrics and methods for the evaluation of the digital transformation of organizations the framework has ben validated by aplying it to sample of italian museums and aditional interviews with museum directors the authors propose framework evaluation composed of five main dimensions people technology proces customer and strategy investment these dimensions are further implemented in subdimensions measured through set of questions the weighted average of results by dimension and subdimension suported the development of an index organizational digital readines composite this document is based on qualitative methodology quantitative composed of two main steps the first step is based on qualitative methodology and consists of scoping literature review aimed at theoreticaly develop the framework the second step is based digital readines index in quantitative methodology which consists of aplying the framework to the empirical environment of italian museums in this study initialy used like for like aproach weighing then those factors were asigned that were considered more influential acording to the interactions with experts in the field who in the environment empirical work of cultural institutions was represented by the museum asociation and policy makers the ministry of arts and culture in more generaly weight alocation depends on the industry specific and should be based on expert validation the aplication of weights to the value of each dimension and subdimension resulted in the synthetic indicator of dri the dri calculation for the sample of museums suported not only the analysis at the organizational level but not to an industry based analysis which also suported the corelation analysis betwen the dri and other variables such as anual number of visitors or the type of colection observations the article presents the complete guide for the transformation maturity calculation digital source prepared by the as result of the evaluation of existing studies related to this ned it was determined that none of curent studies satisfies the requirements and there is research gap in this field to comply with this maturity of the digital transformation ned solution aproach was determined the organizational development of to guide organizations in their dx activities based on wel established pcm spice in the second phase the dx cm was developed using the six step development framework is scope design population testing implementation and maintenance to develop in way structured the multiple case study aproach is used for the validation of the after validation the is available in the implementation phase for anex mtd characterization shets mtd characterization shet generalization and standardization of the as final step of the maintenance phase the ensures its relevance continues through longitudinal study the dx cm is developed by identifying dx proceses the developing proces definitions for dx proceses and the development of the measurement framework for determining of the level of capacity and maturity panel was formed experts composed of five senior academics co the end to identify the dx proceses in the model after develop proces definitions for dx proceses and the measurement framework for determining the level of capacity and maturity the expert panel reviewed the dx cm developed and provided fedback the third phase covers model validation with case study multiple that takes place in two organizations that they operate in two diferent industries in two countries with diferent levels of dx adoption the dx cm must include both management oriented constructs and technology oriented and should focus both on the proceses oriented to management and technology observations the the literature was caried out with flow step specific search proces alowed to select information from relevant studies found in databases considering existing and al the scientific literature on the topic worldwide this research uses hypothetico deductive aproach that includes study of existing theories formulation of research problem based on questions theoretical and empirical discoveries proposed solutions that consist of conjectures or models deduction of consequences in the form of hypotheses suitable for testing the phenomena investigated and prof of falsifiability that encompases eforts to refute hypotheses by observation experimentation simulation or others procedures the cube is created with dimensions enabler organizational technological enabler and enabler of proces maturity subdimensions and elements readines including scale of to to evaluate readines technological aproach of the company level the model was aplied in two situations the first was practical busines culture preparation and negotiation of ofers digital tols implementation post sales digital skils and customer loyalty indicators method the research aproach consisted of two methods of separate research that complements each other first we conducted systematic review of the maturity level by phase of the literature proces to colect information on the state of the research on md and deriving maturity dimensions sales digital for sales from literature this was folowed by exploratory single case study that aimed to specify the identified dimensions of each phase of the project sales proces and generate subdimensions and analysis of the degre of maturity of the digital transformation of an organization mtd characterization shet characteristic items for each phase as method of data colection qualitative interviews were used experts as part of the case study based on the identified maturity dimensions and the elements of maturity we then conceptualized new dm for the project sales to measure the digital maturity of the individual phases in the project sales proces the digital maturity model was adapted to an evaluation tol suposing that the identified subdimensions fuly describe the digital maturity of the uper phase the maturity level of phase is calculated from the arithmetic mean of the maturity levels of its subdimensions whose maturity in turn it is measured by the elements subordinate to it for each subdimension company evaluates the extent to which the coresponding elements are implemented the elements particularly relevant for maturity digital such as the presence of vr mr tols for acquisition talks have greater weighing in general company can obtain minimum of and maximum of points in each subdimension from the arithmetic mean of the scores of the subdimensions and their subsequent rounding you can determine the maturity level of an entire phase he developed specific descriptions for the levels of phase specific maturity however due to smal number of subdimensions and articles it was not posible to determine the maturity levels for the preparation and negotiation of ofers furthermore the subdimensions of the first and last phase show great similarities so measurement was not determined separate from the maturity level for the after sales phase and client retention observations the article does not present the at the university of cundinamarca technology has become pilar fundamental strategic that drives inovation and progres in al areas of our academic comunity recognizing the transformative role that technology plays we embarked on the formulation of strategic plan of information technologies peti that closely aligns with our institutional goals and respond to the changing demands of the digital environment contemporary in this context the strategic importance of technology in our university becomes increasingly crucial both in improving proceses educational as wel as in the optimization of administrative management within this scenario of growing relevance peti is presented as invaluable strategic oportunity to enhance the eficient use of technology in our institution inspired by the principles of the national development plan colombia world power of life where the democratization of ict and the generation of oportunities for colombians through technology we aim to identify and fuly exploit oportunities emerging in the technological field that alow us to optimize our infrastructure strengthen our conectivity and enrich the educational experience and administrative for our entire university comunity in line with the regulatory framework outlined by decre of and its focus on digital transformation and strengthening internal capabilities the peti seks not only to consolidate our curent eforts but also to chart clear and efective roadmap for the strategic adoption of technology in al facets of our university through multidimensional aproach that encompases from improving conectivity to integrating technologies emerging peti represents an oportunity to promote excelence academic and administrative in our institution thus guaranteing solid and progresive in the constantly evolving technological environment aim design and implement strategic information technology plan peti in the university of cundinamarca which in line with the guidelines of the front strategic digital university government established in the development plan designing the university we want focuses on modernization and enhancing the digital experience in al facets of university life this objective is based on the ned to comprehensively plan the evolution of the digital experience to strengthen the interaction betwen students teachers and administrative staf thus promoting eficiency and excelence in proceses educational and administrative peti seks to guide the university roadmap defining projects and technology initiatives and information that align with the neds and oportunities identified by diferent interest groups through the implementation of this strategic plan it is intended to suport the strategy and operating model of the institution guaranteing solid technological environment and advanced that promotes colaboration inovation and continuous growth this strategic aproach seks not only to improve it management but also to enrich the digital experience on the university campus fostering learning environment inclusive interactive and technologicaly updated scope this strategic information technology plan peti of the university cundinamarca main objective is to promote conectivity and digital ecosystems in al university campuses it is proposed the development of comprehensive plan that strengthens the conectivity infrastructure in each of the headquarters with focused aproach on maximizing network aces and sped this aproach comprehensive and comprehensive wil ensure that students faculty and staf alike administrative can eficiently aces the necesary digital resources for academic and administrative development in line with the domains defined in the management model peti wil adres the phases proposals in the guide for its construction how to understand analyze build and introduce the focus of the document wil be on structuring the aligned plan with the strategic motivators identified in the strategic understanding the curent situation and objective of it management in adition there wil be caried out identification of gaps and definition of the portfolio of initiatives projects and shet route that wil suport the democratization strategy of information technologies information and comunication ict proposed by the national government the programing and iteration of the peti wil be caried out in line with the advances of the projects executed and the changing dynamics of the service environment he wil use agile methodologies that alow an agile and efective response to the previously identified fluctuating neds thus ensuring the adaptability of the plan to the evolving requirements of the university comunity regulatory framework id number year description iso technical standard information security guidelines for institutional strengthening in information technologies information and comunications it is the management model on which the it strategy was built for colombia which is model resulting from experience best practices and lesons learned during the implementation of the ict management strategy in the document version last years in the entities of the colombian state it is comprehensive model updated from that is aligned with the busines or organizational strategy and alows the development management model it management that generates strategic value for the organization and its clients this it version made up of the folowing components it strategy it governance analysis information information systems management of technological services apropriation and use strategy for action national strategic framework the national government through the national planing department dnp has raised in the national development plan colombia world power of life strategy to democratize information technologies and comunication ict with the purpose of promoting society of knowledge and technology that is conected to knowledge and global circuits this initiative seks to integrate al actors in the ecosystem including the government the industry academia and citizens in order to acelerate the reduction of the digital divide in the country within this strategy six fundamental lines of action are established that serve as pilars for its implementation conectivity conect more regions of the country especialy the most sections at the service of the internet promoting education and productivity knowledge society promote the apropriation of ict in the government productive sectors education health and the countryside suported by literacy and conectivity to reduce the digital divide secure ecosystem promote the provision of beter ict service with focus promotes citizen security and prevention increasing legality in the sector as wel as the responsible use of ict prevention inclusion of best international practices for the promotion of regulatory compliance providing tols to security service providers internet landline and mobile telephony postal and television strengthening the industry strengthen comunications and services television radio and postal sector of the country through conectivity audiovisual content promote the development of digital content and media publics through the use of pedagogical techniques and clear language aproach with high quality standards in the specific context of the university of cundinamarca the design wil be prioritized of inovative strategies for technological inclusion which wil contemplate holistic aproach that integrates diversity and inclusion within the framework of digital transformation these strategies wil be aligned with the objectives set by the national national development plan and the udec development plan seking ensure equal participation of al comunity members university in the use and apropriation of ict the strategic plan for information technologies peti for the period of the university of cundinamarca wil be based on these strategic lines of digital democratization intertwining each of them with the proposed initiatives the proceses and services of the institution the objective wil be to suport compliance of national directives and at the same time direct the university towards formulation of projects that respond to the real neds of the comunity university the generation of public value wil be ensured the strengthening of it management and the development creative interherd and maple with total value of information systems development requests in the proces of developing information systems the area requests requirement to solve ned the systems development area must provide an initial response within maximum period of days indicating how it wil be adresed the request received either through prioritization or through another development alternative after that the technological solution is prioritized and aproved most apropriate to satisfy the stated ned prioritization is caried out by senior management on the consolidated neds matrix once the prioritization the activities to be caried out are estimated and the status change of the requirement notifying the aplicant about the progres then meting is held to complete and define the development times of the requirement it is important to mention that by new architecture was aplied to the development of information systems within the institution this change reflects focus on inovation ecosystem enginer reyestatsuru shiroku became interested in robots as junior high schol student around fiften years later he harnesed his expertise in robotics hardware and software to can be mounted on construction machines and is capable of controling them remotely from computer tablet or smartphone my imediate goal is to complete the development of autonomous driving technology for construction machines such as hydraulic excavator to enable convenient and safe daily operations at construction sites shiroku said his sights also are set on bringing the construction sector up to sped in digitalization arav enterprises have atracted considerable atention from the construction sector as remedies to adres severe labor shortage and to reduce deaths at construction sites which acount for one third of fatal industrial acidents in japan imersed in mechanical robotics as youth robotics drives digital transformation at construction sites the university of tokyo shiroku hails busines model busines models on the web services portfolio atomic busines models busines structure value creation chanel model busines model functions ontological model case study nubank introduction busines scenarios busines model strategic model portfolio of services motivational component busines structure execution component chanel model capacity map ontological model organizational model busines scenarios information modelintroduction the financial sector has evolved throughout history implementing technology increasingly in its proceses everyday it is increasingly comon that financial products can be requested through non face to face chanels such as the internet or telephone years ago it was inconceivable that something as sensitive as money would be handled with litle or no interaction betwen the client and an advisor this is posible today thanks to new technologies that facilitate the procedures and make it posible for safety checks are done automaticaly with the help of machine traditional banks have sen forced to adapt to changes in the sector and new entrants arive with their inovative technology proposal both share the goal of satisfying client who is increasingly demanding and who has more and more power and financial autonomy from these changes new type of busines emerged financial technology busineses or as they are caled popularly fintech the later have high technological component in their operations and their main advantage competitive is the fredom that the client has to manage their money these busineses have made posible the banking of sector of the population that previously did not have aces to any banking product several fintech companies introduce to market products that are traditionaly physical in digital way then the concept of digital product arises that thanks to its digital nature it alows agility in marketing reduction in operating costs and lower cost of sale than physical product although there are stil many people who prefer traditional products and chanels the the trend to have digital products is growing more and more throughout this document we wil analyze the concept of digital bank using the banking model as framework of reference busines of nubank the world first digital bank which was born in brazil and is founded by the colombian david vélez this analysis wil help to understand the diferences betwen the busines model of traditional bank and digital bank besides we wil analyze the case of colombian fintech which we wil cal fc at the busines architecture level in order to understand the first stages of creating fintech company its motivations and expectations and align them with the market and thus cary out consulting proces for the creation of new line of busines theoretical framework busines models def busines model describes the foundations on which company creates provides and captures value osterwalder pigneur busines model canvas stories strategic management tol consisting of nine creating busines model is like writing new one modules that represent the key components of story this story explains how the busines works al organization to obtain income covering the four the new stories are based on old stories and of main areas of busines customers ofer likewise new busines models are infrastructure and economic viability osterwalder pigneur variations of the most primitive value chain and must be these modules are market segments designed in response to problem many models value propositions chanels customer relations fail because they wrongly asume the form of sources of income key resources activities behave of customers and try to solve key key asociations cost structure ned that does not exist which leads to the busines not generate income and not survive the profits in adition to being value intrinsicaly important are the indicator of the suces of the busines oriented conceptual modeling aproach busines model therefore if the busines model is not electronic busines designed as tol to achieve the expected objectives it must be redesigned and define how value is created and exchanged betwen multiple rewrites until you met expectations without actors thre points of view must be taken into acount however god busines model is not enough on its own value perspective proces perspective and solo perspective god competitive strategy is necesary which systems architecture the value ontology contains competitive advantage with respect to the market and concepts relationships and constraints to describe aliances can be stay profitable there are four types of change models realization renewal extension and trajectory model of realization seks to exploit the ful potential of the curent busines rather than change in the model it uses strategies to optimize its operation with the same resources generaly their strategies are geographic expansion and growth of the customer base renewal model seks to revitalize its products platforms and operations either by creating new products or services or developing new capabilities and atacking new markets an extension model seks to expand industries to monopolize new unexplored market segments functions and operations existing product lines are not changed but rather they ad new ones which means the busines model generaly becomes broader trajectory model means new busines model this drastic change is response to drastic change in the environment these changes are crucial for the survival of company over time busines models on the web busines model is method of doing busines with which manufacturer alows manufacturing company company sustains itself that is it generates profits conect directly with buyer and thus cut internet comerce opens the dors to the competitive strategy is that diferent and dificult to replicate factor that makes company more sucesful than another case study nubank fintech are companies that base their services on financial traditional bank traditional bank vs digital bank before describing the busines model of our case study we wil highlight the diferences betwen traditional bank and digital bank this wil help us begining of his history without however money has also evolved and is becoming les and les necesary poses it physicaly to make transactions the technology available today alows money as digital product enabling transactions to be caried out more easily portfolio of services the services ofered by digital banks are esentialy object of the type of the same that traditional bank ofers the of quantum digital transformation ofice of comunication and marketing freie universität berlin ofice of comunication and marketing exploring the potential of quantum digital transformation launch of the first einstein research unit of the berlin university aliance on the topic of quantum computing from may joint pres release by freie universität berlin humboldt universität zu berlin technische universität berlin along with charité universitätsmedizin berlin how can quantum computers revolutionize the computational power of computers what new insights do quantum computers ofer for high energy physics or quantum chemistry these are the questions that the first einstein research unit eru of the berlin university aliance bua wil adres the interdisciplinary research team of the partner institutions freie universität berlin humboldt universität zu berlin technische universität berlin and charité universitätsmedizin berlin has set itself the task of clarifying the potential of the quantum digital transformation this uniquely brings together expertise in theoretical and experimental physics aplied mathematics computer science and machine learning the einstein research unit perspectives of quantum digital transformation near term quantum computational devices and quantum procesors wil be funded with two milion euros anualy for an initial thre years the funding decision for this first einstein research unit is milestone for the interdisciplinary research landscape in berlin says prof dr ing dr sabine kunst president of humboldt universität zu berlin and spokesperson for the bua in this way the berlin university aliance suports excelent research in the long term in an area that is highly relevant to our society today and in the future quantum computers are considered one of the key technologies of the st century with them scientists hope to solve computational problems that canot be solved nowadays even with supercomputers the continued development of quantum computers also holds great potential for the economy only the technological progres of recent years has made it posible to build the first prototypes of such quantum computers unlike clasical computers they handle information based on quantum mechanical laws this means that memory contents on these computers can at the same time contain multiple superimposed values on which computing instructions have simultaneous efect the research team led by prof dr jens eisert physicist and mathematician at fre university of berlin prof dr oliver benson physicist at humboldt university of berlin prof dr jean piere seifert einstein profesor and computer scientist at technische universität berlin and prof dr robert gütig member of the neurocure cluster of excelence at charité universitätsmedizin berlin explores quantum computing from an interdisc iplinary perspective we are pleased that the first einstein research unit can now be launched freie universität berlin technische universität münchen and are hosting an event about digital education são paulo ofice são paulo ofice the german brazilian digital education forum brings together brazilian and german experts on the various facets of digital education news from oct the fre event aims at promoting the exchange of experiences and ideas regarding digital transformation in education in both countries the german brazilian digital education forum which is aimed at teachers of al levels of education secondary higher education postgraduate masters doctoral and technical as wel as managers of educational institutions wil take place on november betwen pm and pm cet via zom einstein research units excelence strategy freie universität berlin excelence strategy einstein research units bua projects for an integrated research area in berlin how can quantum computers solve computing problems that even supercomputers can solve what can people in the berlin brandonburg region learn about the consequences of climate change for the water suply scientists in the einstein research units want to find answers to these and similar presing contemporary isues by working in tailor made interdisciplinary colaborative groups to adres specific as pects of the isues while funding as part of the exploration projects in the grand chalenges on social cohesion and global health concentrates on the develop ment of new topics and networks the goal of the einstein research units is to anchor the research topics in the university structures the einstein foundation berlin provides up to two milion euros per year for these research units the initial funding period is up to thre years with an option to extend it for another two years through the einstein foundation berlin the berlin university aliance which is funded by the excelence strategy of the german federal and state governments gains aditional funds from the state of berlin so far two einstein research units are being research unit brings together social and natural science as wel as practical expertise from stakeholders to suport the governance of mitigation and adaptation measures in response to climate change cop eration in berlin as location for inovation congratulations on this sucesful work and best of luck for the years to come says müler the ecdf curently hosts profesors who have ben apointed to the acepted their apointments as profesor five apointments are in the ne gotiation stage and seven apointments wil be made in the near future further nine apointments are curently in the pipeline the ecdf unified user interfaces visualisation the world avatar twa bim gis representation of pirmasens house unified user interfaces visualisation the world avatar twa unified user interfaces mobile ap and dashboard unified user interfaces whitepaper how finance and digital twins can shape beter future for the planet alexandra bolton executive director centre for digital built britain mark coates international director of public policy and advocacy bentley systems peter el haj national digital twin programe lead centre for digital built britainforeword alexandra bolton the finance industry has long ben at the forefront of using data and technology to make beter decisions to de risk to improve return on investments and to create beter outcomes tackling the big chalenges of our day climate change and resilience energy healthcare relies on having the right technologies and data to make the right interventions at centre for digital built britain cdb we have sen how digital twins can improve decision making in the planing design build and operation of asets we have also sen the benefits of conecting digital twins acros organisations and sectors the finance comunity has huge oportunity to realise the benefits of digital twins by using them to ad value track sustainability targets atract new investments and manage risk beter however colaboration acros the industry is key when we colaborate acros boundaries acros borders we can do amazing things we can make beter busines decisions that drive beter economic social and environmental outcomes on behalf of cdb would like to thank everyone involved in this paper mark coates and bentley systems for their leadership which was key to making this paper reality and al who so generously shared their expertise experience and knowledge am excited to se how the finance comunity wil join with the wider infrastructure comunity and solution providers to use higher quality data and digital twins to improve investment returns met esg goals and create the sustainable future we al want to se how finance and digital twins can shape beter future for the planetdigital twins centre for digital built britain cdb describes digital twin as digital representation of an aset system or proces what distinguishes digital twin from any other digital model is its conection to the physical twin based on data from the physical aset or system digital twin unlocks value by suporting improved decision making which creates the oportunity for positive fedback into the physical twin digital twin can be dynamic capturing curent performance data from the physical twin or static model of system with input of long term condition data from the physical twin via corporate reporting systems and the capital investment proces how finance and digital twins can shape beter future for the planetbeter outcomes for al how the finance comunity can shape the future of digital twins at the heart of the transforming infrastructure performance programe lies the ned for step change in productivity it wil require data from al parts of the syste to inform decision making from improved information management in delivery to the creation of digital twins for aset maintenance and optimisation nick smalwod ceo infrastructure and projects authority in recent years there has ben an explosion of interest in the potential role of digital twins in the transformation of how infrastructure and the built environment are planed designed constructed and operated modern digital aproaches are at the heart of an emerging government industry change programe captured in the work of the centre for digital built britain cdb and in key documents such as the construction playbok transforming infrastructure performance road map to and the gemini papers during the five years of the cdb programe we have sen step change in the quality of the dialogue betwen industry academia and the public sector it has created greater shared understanding of the use cases and benefits of digital twins at al stages of the aset lifecycle as wel as having unlocked increased investment in digital solutions that have generated ever more economic social and environmental benefits the catalyst for this paper was to ask if the same has ben true for the dialogue betwen an increasingly tight knit industry driving the digital transformation of infrastructure and the investors insurers banks and other institutions who provide much of their funding and finance to answer this question we have spoken with wide range of investors to get beter understanding of how and why they are curently using infrastructure related data as wel as their level of knowledge and interest in the potential of digital twins our conclusion is that there is huge untaped potential for investors to influence how data is used to improve infrastructure decision making and that taking on greater role in the digital transformation of infrastructure wil provide beter outcomes for busineses people and nature there is also significant oportunity to leverage digital twins to suport key chalenges facing the finance comunity where to alocate capital screning and managing risk enhancing aset value by improving performance and reliability and complying with environmental social and governance esg requirements the key to unlocking this potential is to aply the fundamentals of the information value chain the finance comunity can colaborate with the wider industry to develop practical use cases that help them use the insights derived from data to solve their most presing problems make beter decisions and create more value the infrastructure sector neds to play its part and aproach this dialogue with openes and flexibility infrastructure profesionals ned to understand that investors generate their return on investment roi in variety of ways via diferent types of asets and at diferent stages of the infrastructure lifecycle some of their use cases overlap with those al ready developed for suply chain busineses or operators while others wil not in the remainder of this paper we set out thre steps for improving the quality of the dialogue betwen investors and other parts of the infrastructure sector re imagine the information value chain from an investor perspective explore how investors can expand their leadership role and share some use cases investors are curently pursuing finaly in the spirit of encouraging dialogue and colaboration the paper ends with series of open questions that we hope wil kick start debate that wil bring investors into the heart of the efort to digitaly transform infrastructure performance how finance and digital twins can shape beter future for the planetimproving colaboration betwen the finance comunity and the wider infrastructure sector step understanding the variety of infrastructure investors and what that means for the diferent ways that they can benefit from digital twins the first step to bringing investors into the heart of the debate on digital twin adoption is simply to recognise that they are not homogeneous undiferentiated group infrastructure investor is broad term that embraces range of institutions that invest in the debt or equity of infrastructure asets or busineses investors may fund the construction of new grenfield asets or acquire operational brownfield asets there are numerous types of infrastructure investors pursuing variety of strategies to achieve roi private equity firms and aset managers typicaly invest pols of funds on behalf of institutional investors such as pension funds insurers or sovereign wealth funds funds wil hold these stakes for diferent lengths of time depending on their investment strategy but it wil normaly be at least thre to five years fund managers use their expertise to suport aset managers to maximise performance revenues and re sale value they wil normaly receive an anual management fe based on the value of the fund and be entitled not loking to share of gros profits for grand comercial banks provide both debt and equity depending on their investment strategy debt may be in vision ned the form of the purchase of bonds isued by infrastructure aset owners or loans secured against the aset something isuers of debt wil normaly be more hands of than an equity investor and have shorter term interest in the underlying aset scalable institutional investors pension and or sovereign wealth funds may also employ their own interoperable internal teams to invest directly in the equity of infrastructure asets and busineses major players inteligible in the market include big canadian pension funds and the sovereign wealth funds of states such as abu dhabi and singapore and above development banks are national regional or financial institutions that provide debt equity and guarantes al useful for higher risk infrast ructure investments normaly in developing countries that canot be suported in their entirety by private markets development banks are typicaly set up by governments or non profit organisations and normaly operate to policy mandates seting out the social economic and environmental objectives to be suported by the bank activities examples include the european bank for reconstruction and development the new infrastructure bank has many of the characteristics of development bank and is providing gbp bilion of finance to suport climate change and leveling up objectives others key stakeholders include insurers advisors and guarante providers variability of tol roads airport concesion arangement cash flows and seaports grenfield projects that new build utility wil become core asets schol or hospital long and short term post construction projects contracts value aded asets with oportunities data centres revenues from for growth expansion air or seaport expanded services or repositioning expansion asets in emerging markets contracts with les asets in financial distres merchant power reliable counterparties oportunistic generation or asets exposed to waste procesing volatile revenues high level of cost or revenue uncertainty how investors build investment strategies at the most basic level infrastructure is sen as an atractive investment because it ofers stable reliable returns often backed by government counterparty in times of economic uncertainty investments in real physical asets that provide esential government suported services are unsurprisingly particularly atractive behind that general rule however lies variety of aproaches to generating an aceptable roi figure below source preqin shows how the four categories of infrastructure can form the basis of strategies based on expected roi risk apetite and the balance betwen generating returns from maximising revenues or profits from the re sale of asets regulated asets and social infrastructure reimagining the information value chain for investors the use cases investors than for any other organisation colecting data has no inherent value it must be used to make beter decisions that lead to improved outcomes sense making is neded to convert data into insights that can suport this proces this simple idea can be captured in the information value chain the figure above sets out how the information value chain could lok for infrastructure investors source hm government grening finance and roadmap to sustainable investing the sustainable disclosure requirements wil create single integrated framework for decision useful disclosures on esg related isues it wil cover thre categories of disclosures corporate disclosures requirements for companies including financial services busineses to make sustainability disclosures this reporting wil adhere to agred international standards aset manager and aset owner disclosures new requirements for aset managers and aset owners including ocupational pension schemes to disclose how they take sustainability into acount in their decision making investment product disclosure new requirements for creators of investment products to report on the products sustainability impact and relevant financial risks and oportunities this information wil also form the basis of new sustainable investment labeling regime how finance and digital twins can shape beter future for the planet in adition despite brexit the eu sustainable finance disclosure regulation wil afect anyone raising money from investors inside the eu and there are signs that the is moving in similar direction in recent article on infrastructure esg revolution gordon bajnai head of global infrastructure at private equity busines campbel lutyens sumed up the curent situation sectors such as energy and transportation have measurable impact on our eforts to decarbonise the world while sectors such as digital have huge role to play in bridging divides in society esg measument reporting and benchmarking have become standard in infrastructure if you want to raise money these things are must haves and not nice to have this situation is creating big demand for proceses and technology to monitor measure and report on esg risks acros an investor portfolio it also means that esg asesments are playing greater role in due diligence proceses for lending as wel as for the buying and seling of asets by equity investors unfortunately as recent survey published by preqin demonstrates the finance comunity is being held back by lack of consistent high quality data fund manager views on the main chalenges of implementing an esg policy lack of quality consistent esg data confusion over industry terminology shortage of knowledge or expertise political or regulatory uncertainty dificulty in delivering both financial and non financial returns excesive costs lack of consensus from internal stakeholders not relvant to our strategy or mandate lack of quality investment oportunities fiduciary concerns proportion of respondents source preqin fund manager survey november the ned for step change in the quality and usefulnes of esg related data loks like one of the greatest information chalenges facing the finance comunity and perhaps the single bigest use case for digital twin that can create bridge betwen financial data physical asets and the natural environment how can investors take more active leadership role it is necesary for the infrastructure sector to improve how it engages with infrastructure investors in fact it is vital if we want those investors to play biger role in driving the rol out of digital twins of built environment asets investors themselves ned to take the initiative and use their leverage to encourage creating digital twins in ways that align to their interests talking with investors it was once again clear that diferent types of investors have diferent oportunities to take this leadership role one way to think about this is through the lens of investors diferent relationships with the organisations planing constructing and maintaining infrastructure asets how finance and digital twins can shape beter future for the planetdebt incentivising the creation of be ter quality data banks providing debt to infrastructure busineses or project based special purpose vehicles have very transactional relationship they lend money to suport the creation expansion and maintenance of asets and then receive repayment at an agred rate of interest in an agred upon time frame these loans are normaly secured against asets and lenders have first cal on their revenues or resale value if things do not go acording to plan however they wil not receive any share of the upside if the asets outperform therefore lenders oportunities to influence digitalisation are generaly shorter term and linked to their ned to de risk lending and met their reporting and regulatory requirements as eficiently as posible one public private partnership equity investor talked us through how they used spatial temporal digital twin developed for mega project to demonstrate to their banks that risks were being managed efectively during the construction and comisioning phase this technology alowed the investor to secure market leading rates from the consortia of banks providing the debt finance for the project we are also aware of cases like that of great portland estates gpe who in signed gbp milion esg linked revolving credit facility rcf as part of its plan to become net zero by this inovative facility the first to be isued by real estate investment trust incorporates thre esg linked key performance indicators kpis aligned to gpe sustainability strategy these kpis include anual pre agred targets and are based on suporting gpes target to decarbonise its existing buildings and reducing the energy intensity of its portfolio by by suporting gpes target to build net zero carbon new buildings from providing beter quality urban grening measures by increasing biodiversity acros gpes portfolio gpe lenders have agred that decrease or increase of up to basis points wil be aplied to their headline margin based on performance against the kpis in both cases the bank goals were not to drive the digital transformation of buildings and infrastructure these targets incentivise gpe to acelerate the decarbonisation of their busines and wil suport continued behavioural change acros their suply chain however it is easy to se how the existence and use of high quality up to date data linked to the physical asets increased their confidence that construction was being de risked and that esg kpis were being met these examples demonstrate that there is case for big lenders to get on the front fot and be more vocal about the digital information that they want to se alongside the physical asets that they are financing and translate it into competitive interest rates and other returns as one interviewe told us when people price big infrastructure jobs they price what they don know as the information improves they have to go lean because the risks are known equity maximising the value of asets equity investors on the other hand usualy take higher risk but share in increased revenues during the lifetime of their investment and can sel on their stakes at profit therefore their busines model typicaly already involves working closely with owners and operators on improvement plans this situation opens up many more oportunities to drive progres including through digital transformation initiatives it is particularly true for investors with larger portfolios often spread acros many counties one such investor explained to us how they sought to ensure at least base level of digitisation acros the busineses in which they had equity stakes teling us if you have two wind farms and one has some form of digital twin and one just pdf with some anual performance reporting it obvious that for the owner and their enginers the former is les risky and it is clearer where we can ad value then when it comes to re sale asets that have transparent life history are more transactionable how finance and digital twins can shape beter future for the planethis investor explained that they helped local managers to exploit the benefits of being part of the fund portfolio for example helping smaler local utility in one country work with larger busineses in the same sector to aces digital expertise and share knowledge the construction and infrastructure sectors have for decades talked about the importance of inteligent clients many of the equity investors that we spoke with talked about the importance of being an inteligent shareholder big part of which is having plans to increase the digital maturity of their asets government catalysing data sharing for the public god one final category of investor that has leadership role to play is government the public sector provides much of the finance that goes into the infrastructure many of the wider benefits from beter infrastructure data derive not solely from digital twins of individual asets but also from the ability to share data safely and securely acros organisational and sectoral boundaries to realise the systematic benefits of beter data and conected digital twins governments must play catalysing convening conecting and co ordinating role as demonstrated by such initiatives as the cdb own national digital twin programe and the national infrastructure comision data for the public god study our interviews highlighted several intriguing oportunities for government seing benefits the government of quensland in australia is sponsoring the cros river rail project to build new kilometer rail line in brisbane influenced by its conversations with the crosrail project cros river is much more rail the public company delivering the railway has invested heavily in detailed digital twin of the project important th an the potential uses of the model go beyond the delivery and operation and maintenance of the rail embracing infrastructure for example the original goal of the cros river rail project was to monitor the roadway however there are riple efects of this digital twin project the rail organization can now measure trafic in leading edge certain areas and make investments in the right infrastructure our view is that the model has the potential technology to form the basis of city wide digital twin conected ecosystem that can deliver benefits by suporting investment decision making on city wide basis this type of digital twin would deliver value greater than the sum of its parts especialy in the run up to brisbane hosting of the olympics other publicly funded mega projects have leway in their budgets to make these kind of anchor investments they can also use their influence to establish de facto norms for data management and interoperability elsewhere investors are loking to exploit public data sets that might not normaly be asociated with an infrastructure digital twin we spoke to one investor who is exploring how they could align their in house corporate data with public data sets relating to measures such as educational atainment crime and local economic development this aplication would open oportunities for investors to demonstrate how their activity was contributing to policy goals with the potential for more efective alocation of resources and the creation of new income streams for investors the quality acuracy and acesibility of these data sets remain barier to realising this vision despite the eforts of the ofice of national statistics cabinet ofice and others however our investor was convinced that if government worked to make beter quality data openly available private sector players would lean in and develop new solutions to help met national goals like net zero what kind of use cases are investors interested in in our conversations with diferent types of investors we heard about variety of curent and potential use cases here are just few examples how can use data and digital maturity to help increase the value of asets while equity investors have diferent strategies for how long they want to hold on to asets they wil lok to sel on at profit at some point several interviewes told us that they are developing strategies to ensure that asets are more digitaly mature at re sale they are confident that it provides an objective demonstration of high performance and reduced risk that wil increase re sale value enhanced performance wil also increase revenues during the period of ownership and can help crowd in further value enhancing investment how finance and digital twins can shape beter future for the planethow can use data and digital maturity to scren esg impacts and comply with regulations multinational development banks explained to us that they have fundamental ned to demonstrate the impact of their investments against variety of economic social and environmental metrics they told us that they are exploring actively how digital technologies can improve the eficiency and transparency of how impact is measured we also heard from investors in social and economic infrastructure about an oportunity to go beyond esg reporting and open up potential new revenue streams by demonstrating direct corelation betwen their investments and government policy goals such as crime reduction or educational atainment these investors are loking to work with digital specialists to blend publicly available data such as crime figures with their own in house data more broadly investors also face host of esg and safety related reporting requirements these demands are creating one of the most powerful use cases amongst investors for beter data safety the grenfel tower tragedy has ushered in renewed focus from government and regulators on the safety of higher risk buildings the buildings safety act is expected to receive royal asent in the first half of with significant changes to duties around risk management being phased in over the subsequent month period the act builds on the findings of dame judith hackit review of building regulations and fire safety dame judith recomended the introduction of robust golden thread of key information to alow al parties to use information to safely and efectively design construct and operate their buildings she stated that this data must be pased to future building owners to underpin more efective safety management the recomendations and the subsequent legislation are intended to adres the problems within the industry of vital information not being efectively managed or sometimes not even available in usable form to ensure that the right people have the information that they ned to ensure the safety of buildings the act also requires that the data be used to create safety case owned by an acountable person in practice it means acountable persons normaly the landlord or freholder wil ned to demonstrate that risks have ben identified and asesed and that credible plan is in place to reduce or control them to an apropriate level these plans must be maintained and regular reports must be submited to regulators how can optimise energy performance real estate equity investors told us that improving energy performance was the single most apealing use case for digital twins in their world suces would tick esg and carbon reduction boxes while promising to enhance roi via performance improvements and enhanced user experience these investors are actively exploring how scenario modeling and analysis can help identify the interventions with the greatest energy performance benefits how can mitigate risks created by bad data the grenfel tragedy is educating the whole built environm ent sector on the human reputational legal and financial risks created by por or incomplete data the building safety act wil be phased in over the next months introducing the requirement to maintain golden thread of aset information through the lifetime of the highest risk buildings it shows how beter data practices up to and including the creation of digital twins can mitigate the risks created by por data which is an increasingly compeling use case for many investors how finance and digital twins can shape beter future for the planethow can maximise my income from availability payments many investors have revenue streams tied to payment mechanisms based on performance standards such as lane availability on their roads or clasroms heated in their schols these investors are pursuing use cases for digital twins that help investors maximise revenue by ensuring operational teams are alerted when action is neded to head of any drop in service levels this data can also provide historic record of performance useful for proving compliance with contractual obligations over the course of the contract how can reduce my cost of capital one investor talked us through how they used spatial temporal digital twin developed for mega project to demonstrate to banks that the construction and comisioning risks were being managed efectively by the project delivery team this situation alowed them to secure market leading rates from the consortia of banks providing the debt finance for the project moving the conversation forward the goal of this white paper has ben to kick start dialogue that can bring infrastructure investors closer to the centre of eforts driving digital transformation of the infrastructure sector instead of make and how they paradoxicaly very operate to beter serve infrastructure investor interests simple from an investor point in our conversations with infrastructure investors we picked up hint of frustration that some digital twin solution providers focus on pitching the capabilities of technology rather than focusing on investors of view but also problems and how digital twins can provide solutions we were also reminded that investors are not very murky there enginers or digital specialists and ned these solutions explained to them in their language is no blomberg can digital twin their contractual busines neds as first step can they pul together some existing use cases that can realy comunicate and celebrate suces relationships mean information can be can we reach consensus on
