comunity and the infrastructure sector reach consensus on what are the most presing and promising can we set some shared chalenges what level of digital information wil realy be neded to serve them is visualization the requirement or can neds be met at least in the first instance by something simpler should digital maturity asesment be standard part of investors due diligence proces we heard from several investors who have developed simple metrics to ases the digital maturity of the people and organisations in which they are investing they help with risk asesment and identifying oportunities for ading value to the asets and bariers to their realisation should these steps become much more standard part of the due diligence proces is there role for non comercial players like cdb and its sucesors to help codify and standardise digital maturity the sophistication of an infrastructure owner cyber security measures wil be key metric in any digital maturity asesment one development bank told us that many of the projects that they invest in form part of developing countries critical national infrastructure suporting the digitalisation of these nations energy grid or similar projects not only delivers real economic social and environmental benefits but also increases vulnerability to cyber atacks in response the bank has taken very top down aproach to using its leverage to improve data security and standards as wel as ensuring that the maturity exists to maintain them over time how finance and digital twins can shape beter future for the planetin the comercial market we heard to the centre of eforts driving digital transformation of the infrastructure sector the value of information management in the construction and infrastructure sector report estimated that every gbp advance digital twins and unlock their benefits for the finance comunity adopt the gemini principles in your digital strategies cdb is caling on leaders involved in managing and investing in the built environment to build the gemini principles into their digital strategies the principles enable values based aproach for the development of digital twins and alignment for organisations digital twins to suport esg reporting there is great data chalenge facing the finance comunity in terms of aces acuracy and consistency of data this chalenge is on the critical path for esg reporting digital twins should be built on high quality data and there is large overlap betwen data required for esg reporting and data neded for managing of asets advancing the use of digital twins wil drive beter data quality and improve chances for timely esg reporting open data to unlock its value data has value in isolation and an increased value is realised when it is shared and conected open data does not mean that everyone has aces to the data but rather means that data is shareable within the ecosystem of partners clients and the suply chain acording to the gemini principles data must be as open as posible while remaining consistent with the principles of holistic security to create maximum value for everyone including data from many sources is esential to maximising value of digital twins ases and upskil digital capabilities the changes brought by digitisation are driving ned for new services acros the industry such as cyber resilience data enginering data science and software development organisations in the finance comunity should ases digital capabilities and upskil as required to ensure resilient and productive value chain that is fit for the future how finance and digital twins can shape beter future for the planet colaborate the finance comunity is core to the infrastructure industry and is positioned to reap benefits of beter comunication and information sharing acros the industry established comunities like the digital twin hub are great place to shape the future of digital twins in the industry by sharing suces stories and lesons learned as wel as conect to others involved with digital twins cdb has worked closely with the industry academia and the government to explore and create solutions for the chalenges facing the built environment the gemini papers present their learnings from the past five years capturing the consensus viewpoint of the conected digital twin comunity and serving as blueprint for future leaders the finance comunity is in strong position to lead the industry forward next steps join the conversation this white paper is one of the final pieces from the centre for digital built britain which completes its mision at the end of march however many of its activities wil continue including the digital twin hub which has created comunity of infrastructure profesionals who are comited to change as members of that comunity we are comited to working with coleagues to bring investors into the mainstream of the movement and to drive the digital transformation of the infrastructure sector creating beter outcomes for people and the cambridge cb ep ko cam ac uk rs cam ac uk introduction what does it take to sucesfuly adopt and use digital technologies and ofsite manufacturing comited leadership and management digital transformation strategy with realistic objectives building capable suplier network through growing together aproach building trust based relationships with clients training and skils development initiatives for employes robust structures for efective colaboration and comunication conclusion introduction background the uk construction industry has ben frequently berated for its problems of low productivity delays unsafe work practices and the delivery of projects that exced planed costs to tackle these problems the government has ramped up eforts to drive an increase in the use of digital technologies and manufacturing aproaches for delivering construction projects and managing built asets building information modeling bim and ofsite manufacturing osm have ben put forward as the two key inovations that can be used to deliver projects faster cheaper safer and at higher quality the curent industrial strategy is the construction sector deal outlines the government partnership with industry to promote the use of bim and osm to reduce construction and whole lifecycle aset costs by over third reduce delays in construction project delivery and grenhouse gas emisions by half in the construction playbok recently published by the cabinet ofice sets out how the government is prioritising the deployment of these inovations through public sector procurement in order to make their use mainstream in the construction industry for any of these goals to be achieved the construction industry neds to embrace the use of bim and osm on large scale however this wil only hapen if construction firms consultants general contractors specialist subcontractors are able to adopt and use bim and osm sucesfuly despite this critical ned for engagement both take up and use remain low there are several reasons for this and the lack of evidence of the real benefits of the use of bim and osm has made construction firms reluctant to embrace their adoption wolstenholme never waste god construction leadership council inovation workstream buildings isue april construction leadership council house of lords of site manufacture for construction building for change oral and writen evidence presented to the uk house of lords london despite this some construction firms are sucesfuly using bim and osm the experiences of these firms can provide useful learning for other construction firms about this guidance this guidance document describes six key factors that wil help construction firms to transform their project delivery through the adoption and use of bim and osm our research has shown that construction firms that have sucesfuly adopted and are using bim and osm share six comon characteristics comited leadership and management digital transformation strategy with realistic objectives competent suplier networks built through growing together aproach trust based relationships with their clients wel developed training and skils development initiatives for employes and robust structures for efective colaboration and comunication the insights shared in this guidance draw on interviews with over construction industry stakeholders in the uk contractors consultants and clients who have undertaken comercial residential and infrastructure projects acros the country and overseas nine recomendations are put forward in this guidance document designed to guide construction firms taking steps to adopt and use bim and osm the recomendations are specificaly targeted at senior executives and managers of construction firms regardles of size who can implement initiatives to enable their firms to adopt and use bim and osm or improve what is already in place what does it take to sucesfuly adopt and use digital technologies and ofsite manufacturing figure ilustrates how the leadership and management of firm is crucial for creating framework within which al the other factors can be implemented it also shows how implementation of these factors has both internal and external implications for firms figure enabling factors in the sections that folow each factor is described and suported by relevant industry examples and key recomendations for implementation by other construction firms comited leadership and management firm neds comited leadership to suport the proces of change having leader who wil champion the digital transformation vision within firm is esential for suces transformation agenda canot focus solely on technology but must consider individual practices and internal culture in order to sucesfuly establish new ways of working among employes for transformation strategy to trickle down through firm leaders ned to believe in the strategies they are implementing leader champion can be an executive or manager who believes in the urgency of digital transformation its long term benefits and who is comited to implementing the necesary strategies to achieve the vision this wil involve comunicating the digital strategy and vision in ways that apeal to employes and their work related aspirations engagement neds to be personalised and people focused and spearheaded by manager or comite who understands this and is able to comunicate clearly and coherently acros al areas of the firm and its suply chain suportive leadership culture values employe sugestions ensuring that input from employes is treated in way that shows that they are valued is important because this has direct impact on employes wilingnes to be part of the transformation factor that can either constrain or facilitate digital transformation when employes se that their sugestions have ben implemented in company practices it can bost their participation in the digitalisation agenda to ensure that employes are genuinely involved in the transformation journey it is crucial for management to comunicate regularly and clearly with employes and be open to receiving fedback this is important for sucesful digital transformation leadership training resources are available through the construction industry training board citb thre years funded scheme giving leaders the skils to drive digital transformation the national construction colege nc management and supervisory courses and the suply chain sustainability schol range of courses al designed to give leaders in construction firms the skils to drive digital transformation technology transformation aproach that works industry example multiplex multiplex is leading global construction company operating in australia india canada europe and the midle east that uses inovative technologies to execute large scale and complex projects in residential mixed use education health and civil infrastructure developments the firm employs over people based on its latest turnover it ranks th in the top uk construction companies list in multiplex were judged to be the most inovative contractor at the building inovation awards acording to their digital transformation executive fred blogs much of multiplex eforts have focused on employe engagement and cultural change multiplex leadership strategy is people focused and guides their digital transformation agenda where new technologies and practices are introduced employes are treated as individuals and their carer aspirations are taken into consideration in paralel with the task changes that wil ned to take place internal and external inovation competitions are used as strategy for motivating employes to gain recognition for digital inovation internal competitions recognise project teams that have over year ben able to met specific targets related to the use of digital technologies recognition by external industry awards also serves as big bost for the team since they know they are working in one of the best firms in the industry when it comes to using these digital inovations recomendations apoint digital transformation leader champion it is crucial for construction firms to apoint person or team who wil champion the transformation vision and who is comited to the urgency of digital transformation and who wil drive and overse the implementation of digital transformation plan the leader champion neds to hold an executive or management position as this creates employe confidence in the transformation vision and agenda profile _finlr_nov pdf lead by example senior executives and managers in construction firms implementing digital transformation plan should aim to drive the vision internaly at every oportunity and on al projects leadership by example demonstrates comitment to the digital transformation agenda showing how the vision can be realised through everyday internal and project related activities leaders should foster employe confidence in the vision the implementation strategy and the expected outcomes from the transformation journey lead people don focus solely on technology whilst geting the right technology is important focusing atention solely on technology tends to relegate an important aspect of achieving digital transformation changing people perspectives it is important to develop leadership plan that focuses on enabling people to fulfil their potential whilst embracing the use of new technologies leadership that focuses on changing the minds of people by apealing to their individual work related aspirational goals enables employes to achieve goals for the use of digital technologies digital transformation strategy with realistic objectives digital transformation strategy is plan that shows where firm is at outlines vison of change and provides guidance for how that change wil be achieved in the future clear digital transformation strategy should be developed and implemented by construction firms seking to make greater use of digital technologies and osm sucesful digital transformation strategy provides step by step map of how to create new firm culture around the use of new technologies tols are available to help firms ases their curent digital capabilities and competencies and to benchmark them against potential competitors so that future actions can be improved construction firms seking to undergo digital transformation wil benefit from undertaking such an asesment prior to developing their digital transformation strategy digital strategy should be geared towards establishing new routines and practices and creating new firm culture with focus on people proceses routines and technology our research sugests that digital strategy that achieves transformation uses simple language to comunicate the goal of transformation gives employes sense of shared ownership in what is to be achieved is consistent and can be repeated acros the firm considers the neds of people employes in introducing new technologies and proceses and transformation in construction mckinsey company the next normal in construction acesible via nsights the next normal in construction executive sumary_the next normal in construction pdf oliver wyman the time is right to set up real digital strategy in construction acesible via web files oliverwyman_digitalization_in_the_construction_industry_web_final pdf rics how to create digital culture in construction firm acesible via insight future of surveying data technology create digital culture mckinsey company decoding digital transformation in construction acesible via transformation in construction provides the neded internal suport structures for implementation training and suport for staf apropriate software industry example wilmot dixon wilmot dixon wd is leading multi award wining uk construction company that ranks th among the uk top construction companies the firm has over employes involved in its residential and non residential construction interior fit out and refurbishment projects at wilmot dixon there is national digital strategy for al its busineses core to this strategy is the use of bim as busines as usual for al projects regardles of clients requests divisional and regional managers are responsible for adhering to this and are tasked with efectively and consistently comunicating the strategy to their teams digital managers from its six regional local construction ofices lcos contribute to this strategy by proposing aditional local strategies that align to the national digital this aproach enables direct employe input to fed into the development of the national wilmot dixon digital strategy given the large size of the firm and alows lcos to incorporate any unique digital neds of clients and projects into the overarching national digital strategy through the local strategy the national and local strategies are therefore aligned to achieve the same transformation objectives the incorporation of local digital strategies by the lcos has created an avenue for employes to propose new digital technologies for consideration prior to adoption new technologies are examined to ascertain their fit with the company strategic goals and proceses this step provides an oportunity to establish the individual and colective benefits for internal operations and on projects this creates an awarenes among employes of the positive benefits yielded by the digital strategy at the local level and acros the entire firm the construction index top construction companies acesible via recomendation design simple clear and people focused digital transformation strategy that can be easily comunicated construction firms regardles of size ned to develop digital strategy that sets out realistic transformation objectives in plain language it should be simple easy to understand and consistent it should be consistently comunicated acros al levels and areas of firm and repeated until new firm culture has ben established it is very important that senior executives and management suport and drive the development of the strategy alongside their employes jointly creating digital transformation strategy is critical for ensuring that employes have shared ownership of the vision and objectives that the strategy articulates building capable suplier network through growing together aproach construction firms ned to ensure their suply chain has the necesary skils and capabilities to deliver projects using bim and osm to achieve this they may ned to suport their suply chain to develop these capabilities firms operating as supliers in the construction suply chain are critical for sucesful project execution as contractors are heavily reliant on their suplier networks including general specialist trade subcontractors whilst some contractors have developed capabilities to use bim and osm not al of the firms they work with in their suplier networks wil have such capabilities the sucesful use of bim and osm on projects requires that supliers also have the necesary level of skils and capabilities this may involve firms helping to equip subcontractors so that they can use the same or similar hardware and software or tols when working on projects using bim and osm there are resources available for construction firms to ases their suplier network neds as part of their digital transformation programes some of the large contractors interviewed are adopting growing together aproach to build and upskil suplier network with the necesary capabilities for working on projects that involve the use of bim and osm this suportive aproach involves hosting workshops training sesions and company visits to learn of capability chalenges and to ofer training suport to supliers by adopting this aproach firms have learned about the chalenges faced by their supliers in terms of the digital skils of their staf hardware software and training neds and as result they have ofered bespoke asistance to adres these neds this aproach has also enabled contractors to share the digital and manufacturing capabilities neded for future projects this transparency ensures that suplier firms aware of what they wil ned to kep working on projects with the contractors and is considered to be win win aproach to building competent suplier network the growing together aproach has proven to be particularly useful for construction firms seking to make the transition to using bim and osm with their suplier network building on working relationships that have developed over the years deloite disrupting busines models digital suply networks acesible via industry example skanska skanska is one of the world leading construction and project development companies operating in the residential and comercial property sectors in the nordic region europe and usa skanska has around employes based on their latest turnover this multi award wining company ranks th among the uk top construction companies with their suply chain delivering around of the company turnover skanska digital capability relies heavily on suply chain transformation skanska recognises the ned to suport its suply chain as part of sucesfuly implementing its digital transformation strategy the firm is eager to maintain their longstanding working relationships with these supliers because they have built lot of trust with them part of their aproach involves providing their supliers with aces to training ofered by the suply chain sustainability schol of which skanska is founding member in partnership with the citb the fact that the resources provided are fre to use removes one of the major bariers to upskiling the suply chain another of skanska strategies involves increasingly chalenging their suplier network partners to explore the use of new technologies on projects skanska encourages their supliers to develop the capabilities neded to work with them using these technologies using strategy caled inovation push growing together strategy involves providing the requisite training workshops and regular comunication necesary to inform firms in their suplier network about digital technologies that can be adopted for doing things more quickly and with les labour as wel as how to use more of site aproaches this provides skanska with oportunities to kep their suply chain partners informed about the digital capabilities required for specific projects continuous engagement with their suplier network partners means that skanska is able to learn about capability gaps and suport them in learning proces towards improvement this focus on developing their suplier networks has ben key component for the sucesful implementation of projects using bim and osm recomendation suport your suply chain to develop their digital and osm capabilities large contractors should aim to asist firms in their existing suplier networks to improve or build capabilities in using bim and osm for projects doing so wil save time and resources in establishing new working relationships and in building trust with other firms they may not know wel it is therefore helpful to suport trustworthy and high performing supliers to develop relevant capabilities for using digital technologies and osm this growing together aproach can be achieved through the hosting of workshops and training sesions with subcontractors in order to understand their neds and jointly develop plans to help their development there are mutual benefits to be gained in doing this strong suplier network equiped with digital and manufacturing capabilities is crucial in demonstrating relevant capacity at the tendering stage of projects and critical for sucesful project delivery building trust based relationships with clients clients are key players who can drive inovation in the industry and obtaining their buy in is crucial in order to increase the use of digital technologies and ofsite manufacturing this is particularly important for private sector clients who are under no obligation to use any specific technology or aproach for their projects unlike public sector clients who are obliged to require the use of bim and to give presumption in favour of using osm where it could lead to value for money clients are typicaly concerned about geting the job done at the lowest price in order to maximise returns on investments and using digital technologies and osm is often sen as generating aditional costs which clients are usualy not wiling to bear convincing clients about the use of bim and osm therefore begins with wining trust building trust relationship usualy takes time and involves honest comunication ofering reliable information about the inherent risks and the benefits asociated with these inovations it also involves meting agred expectations regarding the use of bim and osm having mutual respect for values and maintaining god reputation by folowing contractual requirements industry example multiplex at multiplex combination of aproaches is used in order to educate clients and to present them with the busines case for the use of digital technologies fundamental to al the strategies used is building trust at multiplex building trust with clients is achieved by being transparent at the outset about the suitability of specific digital technologies for projects and their posible benefits and by ofering critical profesional advice on suitability for every project they actively engage with clients to ases which aspects would benefit most from the use of specific digital technologies and involve them in selecting suitable technologies for the job from an early stage in the project this aproach enables otherwise reluctant clients to se the usefulnes of the technologies for their projects multiplex relies on visual comunication tols including modeling and virtual reality in order to demonstrate the benefits of digital technologies regularly updating clients on ipa government construction strategy london ipa ipa proposal for new aproach to building cal for evidence infrastructure and projects authority london ipa badi ochieng nasaj papadaki technological organisational and environmental determinants of smart contracts adoption uk construction sector viewpoint construction management and economics project progres using these same tols as wel as drone fotage of ongoing work helps to bost client trust and increase confidence in the use of inovative technologies for future projects recomendation build transparent long term trust based relationships with clients construction firms should make deliberate eforts to demonstrate the value of using digital technologies and osm for project delivery to clients this requires building relationships based on mutual trust over time through profesional advice and clear and consistent articulation of the potential financial and sustainability gains to be made from using digital technologies and osm being able to demonstrate that the promised benefits and savings were delivered is crucial to maintaining that trust training and skils development initiatives for employes employes ned to be suported to develop the necesary skils and competencies to enable them to engage with digital technologies and osm rather than asuming particular level of digital competency firms ned to establish baseline of individual competencies so that employes can start their skils journey at the right level for them the digital competency scale provided by the citb is god resource for undertaking this task as it helps to identify which groups of employes ned which specific skils and competencies the suply chain sustainability schol also has wide range of programs available for training employes at diferent levels of competencies to complement these bespoke or one to one training which is tailored to individual digital literacy is crucial in adition it is useful to provide al employes with the basic skils for operating any underlying platform prior to introducing aplication software as part of digital transformation programe companies should bear in mind that soft skils training including colaborative skils system thinking and comunication are as fundamental as hard skils industry example kier kier is leading uk construction and infrastructure services company with almost employes ranking second among the uk top construction companies this multi award wining company was also shortlisted for recognition under the category of the best skils training inovation at the building inovation awards as part of their digital competencies training kier provide in house training designed in line with kier digital transformation agenda the training involves regular one to one metings betwen bim cordinators and design and project employes and aims to identify digital learning neds and asign employes to learning sesions that wil provide them with the requisite skils and knowledge about software programes and proceses these sesions are designed to take acount of individual knowledge and skils regular drop in sesions with refreshments encourage eople to get answers to their questions and help overcome any embarasment that might arise when asking questions in more formal seting recomendations upskil employes in the use of new software and adapting to modified proceses upskiling employes is priority for construction companies in the journey from conventional methods of working to the use of digital technologies atention neds to be paid to helping employes adapt to new technology driven proceses and software changes creating oportunities for employes to take the initiative in learning about the use of digital technologies is also critical to this end companies should suport their employes to undertake relevant training courses provided by relevant institutions including the citb british standards institution bsi royal institution of chartered surveyors rics and suply chain sustainability schol provide tailored training based on employe digital competency levels employes ned to be equiped with soft skils and generic and role specific competencies not everyone neds to know everything but al employes should achieve competencies in the use of certain basic digital platforms microsoft teams skype and microsoft ofice incorporating clear competency profiles into role descriptions ensures that employes understand the skils they are expected to have and the tols they are expected to use uk bim framework bs en iso guidance part proceses for project delivery rd ed acesible via procedures training course robust structures for efective colaboration and comunication as construction firms sek to make more use of bim and osm they ned to establish new ways of comunicating that facilitate greater colaboration and the sharing of data and information colaborative work design and model analysis based on shared information systems requires changes to traditional work practices and routines these become more complicated where multiple firms work on project colaborative design practices require diferent profesionals coming together to work together in cros functional teams firms should aim to develop team structures that place les emphasis on control and strict diferentiation in the functions of teams it analysts designers project managers rather creating cros functional teams with structures that promote frer comunication encourages colective creativity in problem solving and encourages employes to take the initiative when working with new tols technologies or implementing new proceses teams ned to work with software platfor ms that can talk to each other and are interoperable as easy comunication can reduce the likelihod of conflicts and enhance colaboration efective colaboration and comunication using bim are not compatible with traditional methods of organising and sharing information such as physical files and construction firms wil ned to change their systems of data capture storage and sharing of quality data implementing changes to how data is captured shared and stored should be preceded by the disemination of clear documentation in digital format this should set out the deliverables and data expected from each department inside the firm and from each party in the project suply chain construction firms ned to embrace electronic means of sharing information in order to facilitate seamles work with others efectively acros multiple teams guidelines for data integrity and acuracy ned to be established as wel as clearly defining the responsibility of each employe regarding data input and security puting such papadonikolaki van oel kagioglou organising and managing boundaries structurational view of colaboration with building information modeling bim international journal of project management te davies whyte modular designs and integrating practices managing colaboration through cordination and coperation research policy wensven how organizational structure contributes to digital transformation forbes acesible via transformation sh adeba protocols in place is esential to establish new practices and greater colaboration and comunication that wil suport wider use of bim and osm industry example isg isg one of the world most dynamic construction services companies is ranked th in the uk top construction companies and was the winer of the construction news award for suply chain excelence their worldwide specialists in fit out technology and construction deliver buildings in europe the midle east and asia to facilitate efective comunication isg operate horizontal structure that has two senior managers leading two teams of twenty four members this structure enables bim managers bim cordinators and bim technicians to raise diferent isues among themselves and to suport each other as wel as other stakeholders as part of this structure for comunication employes write wekly reports to senior manager about the chalenges they have encountered when using bim or other digital technologies teamwork is fundamental to isg digital strategy and employes are encouraged to comunicate with each other regularly quarterly gatherings alow employes to share information with coleagues about projects about new technology or software being used or about chalenges faced to ensure efective comunication with firms in their suply chains isg provides its suply chain partners with detailed documents outlining expected deliverables and timelines as part of the project comunication ahead of metings they also hold regular metings with their project partners to ases the deliverables at each stage and to discus next steps recomendation create enabling structures for efective comunication and colaboration developing structures that wil facilitate efective comunication and colaboration both internaly and with suplier networks involves the creation or restructuring of cros functional interdisciplinary teams establishing inter disciplinary teams wil enhance colaborative working and neds to be prioritised it wil have the aded benefit of helping profesionals from diferent disciplines learn how to work efectively with others using the same or similar digital tols and software firms ned to ensure that bim and osm platforms and systems used for design functions can talk to each other in ways that do not result in any data los as this could lead to miscomunication and potentialy create conflict furthermore construction firms should convert data and information formats into digital versions for easy sharing acros platforms internaly and acros project suplier networks in timely maner and at diferent project stages riba stages conclusion this guidance has presented six factors identified through research and industry examples that are critical enablers for construction firms to adopt digital technologies and to make greater use of osm comited leadership and management digital transformation strategy with realistic objectives building capable suplier networks through growing together aproach building trust based relationships with clients training and skils development initiatives for employes and robust structures for efective colaboration and comunication the guidance emphasises the importance of having clear digital transformation strategy guiding journey of change backed strongly by leaders who believe in the transformation vision and who work with and train their employes in order to achieve the goals of the vision building transparent trust based relationships with clients by ofering reliable profesional advice about the use of digital technologies and osm is also important building structures that enable colaboration enhance clear comunication and prioritise fedback is also crucial for construction firms seking to sucesfuly adopt and use bim and osm we have outlined nine key recomendations to guide construction firms in taking st eps to adopt and use building information modeling bim and ofsite manufacturing osm apoint transformation leader lead by example lead people don focus solely on technology design simple clear and people focused digital transformation strategy that can be easily comunicated suport your suply chain to develop their digital and osm capabilities build transparent long term trust based relationships with clients upskil employes in the use of new software and adapting to modified proceses provide tailored training based on employe digital competency levels and create enabling structures for efective comunication and colaboration implementing these recomendations wil alow construction firms to sucesfuly make the internal changes that wil alow them to adopt and use bim and osm for project delivery the authors are grateful to al of the industry partners who participated in the research that informed digital capabilities framework construction inovation hubmain menu the framework explained the framework covers thre main areas digital capabilities practice and discipline specific capabilities and the context in which the work is undertaken it draws on task based capability frameworks that have ben sucesfuly generated for enginering disciplines and for solving real work problems in short industrial placements developing an activity framework to suport teaching and learning the framework is intended to be aplicable sector wide and is distinct from discipline specific competence frameworks providing role based standards at several levels of proficiency foundation practitioner and expert digital capabilities framework construction inovation hubmain menu digital capa bilities the research identified thre overarching groups of digital capabilities general digital capabilities discipline role capabilities built environment core digital capabilities these are enablers of learning and these relate to the efective deployment these are the core digital capabilities that digital work within and beyond the built of specific tols systems technologies were identified through transformingconstruction city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region publishable report date required july abstract the project explores the posible impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work through the development of city level digital twin cdt prototype that integrates data models and insights from multiple disciplines and sectors the research includes thre work packages empirical investigation of key factors afecting worker choice on place of work fixed workplace work at from home and on travel mode in the cambridge sub region developing digital twin prototype including web based interface for simulating journeys to work and testing two digital transformation scenarios prevalence of teleworking large scale adoption of electric vehicles engaging with local authorities modeling experts and other key stakeholders to colect fedback on the aplication and future development of cdt productive partnership has ben established betwen the local authorities and the project team for the co development of the digital twin prototype the project also colaborates closely with academics at ucl and cambridge key research outputs are discused in detail and series of working propositions are proposed which may guide the future research on cdt city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region introduction we are living through the th industrial revolution moving from period of relative data scarcity to an era of digital abundance the sher size of investments and eforts for building smart cities acros the globe has epitomized the inspiration for future beter cities in the digital era in the uk the national infrastructure comision has outlined an ambitious plan of building national digital twin of uk infrastructure which aims to demonstrate uk global leadership in smart infrastructure the digital twin brings together individual infrastructure models and the interdependencies betwen them through federated system thus represents cordinated aproach for planing constructing and managing national infrastructure the potential benefits of the national digital twin are aparent optimising use of resources reducing service disruption increasing resilience and bosting quality of life for citizens but how to materialise such benefits through efective policy making remains big chalenge ahead while the digital twin technology is making great strides in the uk with several large scale pilots under construction exeter bristol quen elizabeth park in london or being considered smart cambridge the varying and changing socio economic and political context of the uk cities implies that the digital twin alone is unlikely to be one size fits al solution to city chalenges for example wh ile congestion has ben regarded as prevailing isue acros major cities there are actualy fewer comuting journeys per person per wek in the uk in than the mid this trend has often ben atributed to wide range of transformations regarding the nature of employment such as more part time work more people working from multiple places teleworking increasing self employment the gig economy etc such behavioural changes are complex and wil have profound implications on how we plan use and manage our future infrastructure however understanding such changes requires an inter disciplinary and colaborative aproach the digital twin has great potential for bridging the disciplinary and profesional gaps by incorporating data and insights from multiple sectors thus fostering stakeholder debates over complex trade ofs the project represents an early trial to adres the research gap on city level digital twins it aims to develop digital twin model prototype for examining the potential impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region the report is organised as folows section introduces the study area section discuses the key research outputs section sumarises the potential contributions to digital built britain through proposing series of propositions for guiding future research overview of the study area the core study area for this study is the cambridgeshire and peterborough combined authority which consists of local authority districts given the relatively large comuting catchment of cambridge the modeling area is expanded to cover the former greater cambridge and greater peterborough lep area which consists of local authority districts the study area features the fast growing southern areas cambridge and south cambridgeshire and the deprived northern areas in the fens which represents typical uk city region of significant spatial inequality map of the study area is presented in figure future of travel report by the comision of travel demand demand the cambridgeshire and peterborough combined authority as it stands in the time of writing this report includes cambridge south cambridgeshire east cambridgeshire fenland huntingdonshire and peterborough city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region figure map of the study area zones in dark grey the core study area cambridgeshire and peterborough combined authority in terms of the im balance betwen resident and workplace population in the study region se figure cambridge and peterborough are the only two cities in the study area that have more employed workers than employed residents indicating that workers from other local authorities may have to comute to cambridge and peterborough for work city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region figure resident and workplace population by employment status resident left and workplace right population by employment status workplace self employed part time home place self employed part time workplace key research outputs trend in employment growth the investigation of historic data on employment growth by type se figure below shows that the part time employes and the self employed without employes have ben growing faster than other employment types in the cambridgeshire and peterborough combined authority compared with the number of self employed without employes has grown times and the part time employes have nearly doubled in in particular the self employed without employes who may be closely related to the gig economy se an ever quicker growth during in the study area the ful time employes who acount for of the workforce in have sen steady growth since it can be anticipated that the share of part time workers including both employes and the self employed is likely to raise in the study area suposing the observed trend continues as more people start to engage flexible working flexible working hours working from multiple places it is important to investigate the asociated impacts on the choice of place of work and journeys to work city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region figure change of employes and the self employed in the cambridgeshire and peterborough combined authority understanding the choice of place of work our statistical analysis using census microdata for the study region confirms that being self employed either as frelancer or with employes is more likely to work at from home or have no fixed place than being an employe after controling the cros sample diferences on age socio economic status industry of work broad residence location length of working hours posible childcare duty and housing condition measured by number of persons per rom specificaly the positive corelation betwen the age of individual sample and the choice of working at from home indicates propensity for working at from home when workers get old in the study area higher socio economic status would increase the probability of chosing home working it sugests that high skil jobs managerial and profesional are more amenable to working at from home than relatively low skil jobs semi routine and routine low skil jobs are more likely to have no fixed workplace we also find that the choice of home working is subject to the availability of space in the house as the number of persons per rom increases higher ocupancy level the likelihod of working at from home decreases in the study region the interdependence betwen home working and housing provision subject to further tests using up to date data may shed new light on understanding worker choice of place of work sa emulov deniahc sdnasuoht rebmun change of employes and the self employed in the cambridgeshire and peterborough combined authority own analysis based on uk census sum of employes ful time sum of employes part time sum of self employed with employes sub total sum of self employed without employes sub total employes ful time employes part time self employed with employes self employed without employesa city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region understanding the mode choice for journeys to work the figure below shows the mode share for comuting from the cpca area to cambridge as the workplace using census data segmented by km distance interval note that driving car includes only driving in car van and exclude comuters who are pasengers in car the figure also omits other modes of travel motorcycle scoter or moped taxi as by census definition figure mode share and travel volume for comuting by distance band it shows that for distance under km the predominant mode for comuting to cambridge including those comuting within cambridge is bicycle around folowed by walking and driving however the mode share for driving increases sharply from km reaching about for km and striking for km this is acompanied by the quick drop of bicycle mode it is not surprising as cycling over km about min one way for an average sped of km hr on daily basis may become physicaly undesirable les than of comuters use bus for comuning within the km range the share of bus increases from km but is caped around at around km the share of train for comuting remains under for distance under km with spike around km range waterbeach cambridge and increases to about for km newmarket royston cambridge and km ely cambridge given the local policy goal of reducing car dependence and promote sustainable travel the shift from car to bus and other non motor modes has ben the overarching focus in local transport strategy the figure below shows the ratio of mode share betwen bus and car around cambridge the purpose of producing the map is to emphasize the spatial heterogeneity in terms of the mode choice of car and public transit to adres the desirable shift from car to bus the km comuting distance range is selected within which the bus remains feasible substitute to car for comuting purpose for comuters as pasengers in car acount for about of al comuters to cambridge including those comuting within cambridge al other modes acount for about of al comuters to cambridge including those comuting within cambridge the exclusion thus does not change the analysis results significantly erahs edom emulovlevart mode share and travel volume for comuting by distance band origin the cpca area destination cambridge source census distance band network distance km volume drivingcar bus bicycle fot traina city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region distance beyond km driving car may become advantageous in terms of travel time in figure red line indicates that there is les than one bus comuter by every car comuters along the comuting coridor an orange line indicates that there are les than ten bus comuters by every car comuters figure modal share betwen bus and car for comuting purpose in cambridge and the environs census red line indicates that there is les than one bus comuter by every car comuters along the comuting coridor an orange line indicates that there are les than ten bus comuters by every car comuters for major employment sites in central cambridge the mode ratio betwen bus and car is around indicating that there are more than bus comuters for every car comuters there is rom for further improvement for employment sites on the fringe science park and the biomedical campus the mode ratio betwen bus and car is generaly under indicating les than ten bus comuters by every car comuters the empirical finding sugests that to shift comuters from car to public transit the mobility solutions ned to be more targeted in relation to specific locations and comuting coridors and socio economic background of comuters the spatial and social dimension is very important in policy making without which the behavioral changes expected from policy interventions shift towards public transit are dificult to fulfil city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region insights from big data set automatic number plate recognition anpr in adition to the conventional data sources this research taps into new big data set namely the automatic number plate recognition anpr records to understand the hourly journeys to work paterns in cambridge the local authority is acknowledged for providing the anonymized anpr data the anpr data set aplied covers whole wek mon sun in june to link the data with agregate census data each anpr camera is asigned to midle layer super output area msoa which is the spatial unit of analysis used in our study during the one wek data colection period around vehicles per day can be identified that pas through or stop by cambridge set of rules are proposed to diferentiate comuting cars from non comuting car journeys tourism and logistics the folowing rules are aplied for detecting comuting car which are derived from our own tests broad travel direction towards the city centre determined by the captured trajectory of the vehicle first apearance time stamp betwen am pm duration of stay in cambridge area no les than five hours based on the rules reported above aproximately vehicles per wekday on average are recognized as comuting vehicles the folowing figure depicts the total number of comuting vehicles in cambridge by the hour which includes both stationary and on road vehicles it shows that the total number of comuting cars peaks at non in cambridge figure hourly total number of comuting vehicles in cambridge including both stationary and on road vehicles comuting load by the hour excluding stationary cars can also be obtained from the records se figure the procesed data shows that morning peak in cambridge is betwen am while the afternon peak is pm the comuting patern on friday is slightly diferent from the other workdays with lower volume in both morning and afternon peak detailed investigation into the cambridge biomedical campus cbc yields some local insights se figure for instance majority of workers at cbc tend to come to work at am leading to single point morning peak however the afternon peak at cbs sems to be more spread than the city as whole with more workers remain at workplace after pm we dem that such load patern is related to the particular working schedule midle layer super output area msoa is an oficial census geography more information can be found at ons website city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region of hospital workers such as changing shift in the morning to further understand the patern the mode share by socio economic group seg at the cambridge biomedical campus cbc in census is presented in figure although the two data are for diferent years the composi tion of car comuters by seg in sugests that the seg semi routine and routine workers such as carers cleaners acounts for rather smal share of car users it is the medium to high skil workers contribute to the observed comuting samples makes it dificult to understand the underlying causes of the observed patern linking the data with more structured data such as the census may help adres the analytical dificulty digital platform for understanding journeys to work in the cambridge sub region one of the main analytical dificulties for understanding journeys to work is the high dimension feature of the travel data travel origin destination mode distance time social economic clasification household profile etc as proposed in the proposal web based digital platform is developed to visualize the multi dimensional journeys to work data to prepare the data set we build on the open aces census flow data for the study area which include origin and destination by travel mode or national statistics socio economic clasification ns sec the original flow data is then expanded by ading the breakdown of ns sec by mode through an established land use and transport model aplication for the cambridge sub region the expanded data set thus include origin destination travel mode and socio economic clasification the socio economic segmentation in the data set which is agregated from ns sec is sumarized in the table below from seg to seg it indicates decreasing ranking in grade detail information about the structure and methodology of ns sec can be found at ons website the model aplication is developed for the model based policy analysis can be downloaded here city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region table model user interface of the digital twin platform for journeys to work in the cambridge sub region digital twin model for simulating future journeys to work as informed by the workshop outcomes with local authorities the purpose of the cambridge digital twin cdt model is to bridge the sectoral silos of transport housing environment and energy in local policy making these policy themes are jointly selected by the local authorities and the research team as cros cuting policy isues with local urgency the model development folows policy oriented aproach se figure in terms of time horizon the proposed cdt prototype is focused on the medium to long term policy scenarios in terms of modeling scope the cdt prototype aims to quantify some of the interdependences among transport air quality housing and energy infrastructure in the cambridge sub region in relation to background changes in employment and technology it has ben identified through workshop and interviews that the future location of busineses employment households and their travel choices is the pivot variable set that conects the selected policy themes city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region figure policy outcome oriented aproach for eveloping the cambridge digital twin prototype on journeys to work the cdt pilot is focused on comuting trips journeys to work which is key determinant of peak time travel demand based on the journeys to work data computational digital twin model is developed the proposed digital twin model builds on established transport modeling methods and incorporates new explanatory variables relating to the type of employment and the built environment the modeling workflow is sumarized in figure figure workflow of the digital twin model for scenario inputs journeys to work employment population projection land use and transport development scenarios asumptions on future of work and travel digital twin model for journeys to work model outputs on journeys to residence location work choice travel volume by origin and destination method of travel mode model calibration using mode choice share historic data on journeys to work uk census series city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region the digital twin mode consists of two inter conected components the residence location choice module and the mode choice module the proposed model builds on established transport modeling method and is expanded by ading new location specific variables relating to local employment profile share of the self employed part time workers dweling density and ocupancy level statistical analyses are aplied to inform the selection of variables the godnes of fit of the calibrated mode choice module is presented below figure godnes of fit of the calibrated mode choice model observed vs modeled number of comuters by mode at workplace r² the calibrated model is then used in forecast mode to produce future journeys to work scenarios in the study region informed by the discusion with local authorities two future scenarios are proposed to demonstrate the functionality of the digital twin model prevalence of teleworking and future electric vehicles charging demand which are introduced in turn below scenario teleworking teleworking or remote working represents flexible way of working without comuting to central workplace teleworking enables workers to work from home or other locations for some days of the wek which thus may reduce the overal comuting demand one of the key modeling asumptions pertains to what kinds of employment are amenable to teleworking in the future se table it is asumed that medium to high skil jobs self employed jobs and clerical and administrative jobs are more prone to teleworking based on this asumption the percentage of jobs subject to teleworking in the study area is sumarized in table total of of jobs about jobs based on the presented employme nt projection for cambridge are amendable to teleworking in cambridge devresbo journeys to work by fot modeled vs observed from al locations in gcgp to cambridgeshire travel volume r² modeled devresbo r² journeys to work by bicycle modeled vs observed from al locations in gcgp to cambridgeshire travel volume modeled devresbo journeys to work by car modeled vs observed from al locations in gcgp to cambridgeshire travel volume modeled devresbo journeys to work by bus modeled vs observed from al locations in gcgp to cambridgeshire travel volume driving car van bus modeled bicycle on fota city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work about the cpier report city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region to test the posible impacts on comuting due to teleworking comparative scenario analysis is conducted we first run the digital twin model to generate baseline scenario for the study region using the asumed employment projection sumarized in table the baseline scenario serves as the basis for comparing the relative changes acros scenarios recal that the proposed digital twin model can predict both the residence location choice and the mode choice in the baseline scenario both the residence location and the mode choices are simulated by the model technicaly the prevalence of teleworking would afect both the residence location choice for reduced overal comuting cost per wek and the mode choice for likely increased flexibility in working hours nonetheles there is no empirical data available for estimating the elasticity of household relocation with respect to the reduced wekly comuting cost we thus do not consider the posible residence relocation and asume that in the teleworking scenario al employed residents remain their original home location as in the baseline scenario the scenario result is shown in figure figure scenario output potential reduction of comuting flow by al modes due to teleworking in cambridge based on the baseline scenario northstowe impington cambourne comberton fulbourn duxford it shows that the posible impact on comuting is not evenly distributed acros the study area the teleworking may reduce the journeys to work both within the city and acros city boundary in particular the comuting flow from cambourne comberton northstowe and impington to cambridge may se significant reduction two policy implications may be drawn from this preliminary impact study of teleworking on comuting first the fast growth of self employed and part time workers in the study area since sugests that flexible working arangement such as teleworking may become prevalent in the study area the posible impact on journeys to work could be significant in magnitude city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital tra nsformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region which poses new chalenges to transport demand forecast second the prevalence of teleworking may bring radical changes in terms of the relationship betwen work and location on the one hand the emerging co working space is bluring the boundary betwen jobs and workplace teleworkers search for suitable place to work and fil that workspace but not necesarily job on the other hand planers developers architects and employers ned to consider new models of providing and managing workspace hotdesking not simply reducing the florspace per worker but considering the flexibility and adaptability of space and the wider impacts on workers productivity and welfare some caveats should be noted first literature on tele remote working sugests that the reduction of comuting trips may result in the increase of non comuting trips and the total time budget for traveling in fact remains quite stable over time and among population although teleworking may reduce the demand for comuting for certain types of jobs the impact on overal travel demand is not clear second digital technology is likely to be key enabler for teleworking it involves wide range of technology such as cloud platform imersive technology and the underlying physical infrastructure such as fibre broadband mobile conectivity the teleworking scenario in this study does not consider the availability of such technology in specific locations scenario electric vehicles charging demand the design of this scenario is inspired by one particular finding from the workshops and interviews with local authorities replacing the existing combustion engine vehicles with electric vehicles evs is demed as the ultimate solution to air polution as it adreses the rot of the isue however the large scale take up of evs is subject to the capacity of local electricity grid which is already under considerable strain the adenbroke hospital area this scenario thus aims to adres the interdependences betwen the environment transport land use and energy system in local policy making this scenario asumes that al vehicles comuting to cambridge including those comuting within cambridge are evs to simplify the energy simulation we do not diferentiate the types of evs and asume uniform electricity consumption per km traveled by evs kwh per km source dft webtag the electricity charging demand for non comuting use of evs is also not considered the key policy variable in this scenario is the spatial distribution of future housing and employment growth in the study region se figure total of thre alternative spatial development strategies are tested which are in line with the scenario seting in the cpier report se fotnote on page for more information about the cpier report the digital twin model predicts how alternative spatial strate gies may afect the distribution of evs charging demand acros the study region the prediction for the baseline is presented in figure to highlight the posible impact of nudging people in terms of where to charge the evs we further asume that al comuting evs can only be charged at either workplace or home place the results for the densification and the fringe growth are presented in figure and figure respectively hägerstrand what about people in regional science papers in regional science zahavi the umot project report prepared for the us department of transportation research and special programs administration and the federal republic of germany ministry of transport dot rsa dpw city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region figure evs charging scenario alternative spatial development strategies for cambridge and the environs busines as usual baseline extrapolation based on the historic growth patern for housing and employment densification concentrating the majority of growth within the existing city boundary fringe growth alowing the city to expand outwards on the fringe which requires releasing some grenbelt land for development figure evs charging scenario baseline charging at workplace left vs at home place right city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region figure evs charging scenario densification charging at workplace left vs at home place right figure evs charging scenario fringe growth charging at workplace left vs at home place right city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region policy implications of the evs charging scenario are sumarised as folows high level of spatial variance is observed in the distribution of charging demand for comuting evs the further concentration of employment in cambridge as in the densification scenario results in the highest charging demand in cambridge if comuting evs are al charged at workplace upgrading the energy infrastructure in the dense centre of cambridge is likely to be expensive acompanied with severe disruption to local busineses nonetheles the increased electricity demand may be shifted away to other locations in the short term through pro active pricing policy on charging and or parking at workplace as sugested by the comparison betwen charging at workplace and home place in the figures to make it posible it requires beter colaboration betwen transport housing and energy team in local government the feasibility of shirting evs charging demand betwen workplace and home place is les in the fringe growth scenario as more workers live in proximity to their workplace the improved job housing balance on the fringe also indicates reduced average comuting distance compared with the baseline it should be pointed out that the scenario results are rather crude due to the various simplifications in scenario design the purpose of this scenario is thus not to provide an enginering solution for optimizing the distribution of future evs charging demand but to demonstrate the potential of city level digital simulation tols for facilitating cros boundary colaboration in policy making in local government potential contributions to digital built britain inspired by the uk national infrastructure comision recomendation for national digital twin and the recent progres of the digital framework task group and centre for digital built britain this short project explores the concept of city level digital twin in terms of the design development and aplication through modeling case study in cambridge in light of the gemini principles this project also aims to test and verify the high level principles in real policy context and generate transferable knowledge on city level digital development in aditional to the key research outputs discused in the last section we sumarize series of working propositions regarding the development of city level digital twins which are derived from the cambridge digital twin exercise an early version of these propositions has ben presented on the international conference on smart infrastructure and construction icsic in cambridge it is expected that these propositions wil guide the future research and practice on city level digital twin and thus contribute to digital built britain proposition the upscaling from an enginering digital twin to city level digital twin is not straightforward for city level digital twin aplication to be useful and the asociated discusion to be meaningful key dimensions of the digital twin ned to be articulated pertaining to the purpose boundary context and resolution of the specific digital twin as wel as the interdependences among twin models thre dimensions of such are proposed in figure policy domains stakeholders denote the subject and representation of the digital twin about what and for whom locational context includes the social economic political and geographic background and spatial temporal scale indicates the resolution of the twin model wan et al developing city level digital twin propositions and case study international conference on smart infrastructure and construction icsic january city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region figure key dimensions for defining city level digital twin aplication policy domains stakeholders about what for whom digital twin digital twin digital twin locational context spatial temporal scale proposition digital twin development is progresive proces the digital twin and the social system that creates and uses it must co evolve with each this proposition relates to the intelectual relationship betwen the digital twin and the human society on the one hand our existing knowledge about cities and societies defines how wel we could development and use city level digital twin on the other hand artificial inteligence ai may eventualy become comparable to or even surpas human inteligence in terms of knowledge production and decision making in the wake of recent data misuse and privacy breach incidents the cambridge analytica case the co evolving proposition adreses the imperative for harnesing the power of ai through pre emptive measures proposition real time is relative term the temporal scale of the digital twin should reflect the rate of change of the subject in reality the real time feature as in enginering digital twin aplications denotes the low latency in updating the twin model against the reality the transition from manufacturing product as the subject of digital replica to city entails the term real time to be redefined it contests to the simplistic pursuit of high frequency data regardles of the purpose of the digital twin proposition to advance the city level digital twin agenda digital twin aplications should be focused on enabling more frequent and efective fedback lop betwen the twin model stakeholders and the public one major problem of using urban computational models in policy making is the lack or ineficiency of fedback which can manifest itself in various ways model as black box no post analysis validation and the detachment from public engagement from modeling perspective the implication is that the interaction betwen the model and the users is far from perfect even for modeling experts new interface thus neds to be explored which can translate data analytics into cogent naratives targeted to various stakeholders to achieve it modelers may have to think beyond models which is aparently more than technical request proposition to help solving complex policy chalenges realistic use of city level digital twin is to identify system level risks and ineficiencies of policy interventions and to foster cros disciplinary profesional colaboration as oposed to providing singular model based city level digital twin experiment for exploring the impacts of digital transformation on journeys to work in the cambridge sub region optimization system level optimization though being the explicit purpose of some digital twins in the enginering sphere may not be an efective aproach to adres wicked urban problems one of the reasons is that developers of the digital twin given their technical background often do not have enough understanding of the non tec hnical factors election cycles hierarchies of decision making institutional constraints these non technical factors are usualy highly influential but tend to be very dificult to be incorporated in the model model based optimization which does not consider such non technical constraints would have litle meaning it should be noted that these propositions are neither conclusive nor exhaustive it is expected that the propositions could be further tested and expanded through more empirical research conclusions the digital twin technology represents one of the latest technical trends for smartening our cities however the roadmap to develop city national level digital twin is not yet clear this project represents timely efort to explore policy oriented strategy for developing city level digital twin prototype for the cambridge sub region key research outputs are discused and series of propositions are proposed for guiding the future research on city level digital twin the project is nothing but smal step towards the ambition of creating national digital twin for the uk infrastructure it is expected that more and more empirical evidence wil be gathered to establish new body of knowledge for leveraging and regulating the power of digital twins as discused in one of the propositions the development of digital twin is progresive proces where the digital twin and the social system that creates and uses it must co evolve with each much remains to be done
